reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nuclear Throne is a very well made roguelite twin-stick shooter that incredibly fun and satisfying to play that I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys roguelikes.

There are six different categories of guns; Bullet, Shell, Arrow, Laser, Explosive and Melee. Each one of them feels different and unique so there will be a preferred weapon type for everyone. The gunplay in the game is very well done, all the weapons feel like they have a weight to them and it is fun to mix different weapons to find the perfect combination. The randomized nature of the game means that players will get to experiment and experience all the weapons. Furthermore, it’s very satisfying to learn the how the weapons work and master the controls of the variety weapons.

There are a variety of character which have unique abilities such as rolling and shields and player also levels up their character through the run which will unlock new attributes, leading to some unique builds that will adjust how the player will play the game, meaning every run is unique. There is also daily challenges which will spawn a new run every day and you can replay the same map for a day and try to place on the leaderboard, rather than a randomized level each time, creating a variety of game modes.

Every stage in the game feels unique with new enemies introduced that you learn the patterns. The game has elements of Shmup games with a large amount of bullets flying towards you and can get overwhelming but it’s very satisfying find a path through the enemies and beat the level.

Even though the game can be very challenging, the difficulty curve is not too steep so that it doesn't become too hard for players too quickly, the player is always in a space where it is possible to fight out of any challenge.

The sound design and graphics both build a very unique atmosphere, the music often matches the settings perfectly and is very invigorating when fighting the enemies. The pixel graphics are very detailed and unique that gives the game great charm and character that is wonderful to look at, all the enemies are instantly recognizable and interesting to fight.

This is also a paragon of early access games. The devs have made over 90 weekly updates to the game that add new features such as weapons, characters, as well as adjust and rebalance gameplay. They listen to the community; they deserve some respect for their commitment to the game in a landscape of exploitive developers who want to release buggy, broken games to get a quick buck, such as DayZ and countless other scams.

Nuclear Throne started out a great game and has only gotten better over time as more things get added to the game, as it soon approaches its full release, it sets a standard for early access games on Steam and it is a shame that this level of dedication to a game isn’t seen very often. Overall, definitely worth picking up to support good developers and a great game, looking forward to the final release coming up soon!

reviewText:
I have this game on my PS4, so don't let my playtime fool you.

Where do I begin? This is why we love indie devs! For every Jumpix Jump, there are absulote gems of games like this. I bought it on my PS4 as an impulse buy because I liked the pixel characters. I had no idea what I was in for. I bought it again through Humble Bundle just because I loved it so much. (I know Sony doesn't give indie devs that much revenue.)  I never done that before. I could have given that money to charity. What am I doing with my life? (I don't regret it. I support indie devs!)

This game is the hardest game I have ever played. It's harder then Shovel Knight, Dark Souls and Bloodborne. However, it's not cheap or unplayable like a lot of old NES games. Every mistake is your own fault. Only a few bad spawns made the game feel unfair. Otherwise, this game is based purely on your skill as a player and willingness to learn it's rules. This is great game for speedrunners and competetive players. It takes skill to play this game good. And once you finally master it, it throws a new trick at you.

I am what you would call a casual gamer. I'm not a big fan of difficult games, let alone bullet heaven type games. However, I was immediatly pulled in by this game. I'm addicted. You die and die again, and yet I can't stop hitting the retry button. That is amazing that a game this hardcore could pull in a casual player like me.

I grew up on the NES and the SNES. (I'm young, btw. Second hand gaming rules.) Those are my two favorite systems, and this game feels like it would belong among the most legendary and classic games on those systems. I love the graphics. The pixel art is beautiful. Every character, enemy and stage has their own personality. Obviously a lot of love went into this game. This just goes to show what can be done with Gamemaker studio. I actually really love Gamermaker games when they're done well. I think there's a charm to them.

When it comes to the gameplay, there a million ways to play. Every character has their strengths and weaknesses, and along with various randomized mutations and a HUGE arsnel of weapons - there is a lot you can do! Which really adds to replayability. You can easily get 500+ hours from this little game. It's full to the brim with secrets, character and charm that will keep you coming back for more. As a NES/SNES fanboy, I think this game just trumped a lot my classic favorites. This is my favorite game by far and goes to show why we need indie games. I have plenty of mainstream AAA games with top notch graphics, but I come back to little games like these more often than not.

I can not praise this game enough. It's a little masterpiece of an indie game. What are you waiting for? Get it. Through Humble Bundle if you can, if you want to support this dev more. (Go to the game's website. The link is there.)

I have a few tips for you:

- You will die. A lot. You will get frustrated and grit your teeth and curse this game. Take a break. Play another easier game (preferably Stardew Valley) or put the controller down, and then come back. You'll realize that when you're calm, you're doing better then when you were stressed.

- There is no pointless character. Even if a character seems useless to you, every one is cleverly planned out to have strengths. It's up to you to figure out what those are. (Or you could just look it up, like a cheater.)

- Crystal is BY FAR the easiest character to play as, but I would only play as him if you're just starting and getting used to the game's difficulty. Because of his special ability, learning how to play the game with this character can be counter-productive. You need to learn how to dodge.

- There are plenty of secrets, but most are obvious once you realize how to find them. Keep your eyes open.

EDIT: - Also, there's one more thing I'd like to mention. The screen shakes a bit in partcularly chaotic fights. If this bothers you, there is a setting in the options to turn screen shaking off. I did this and prefer the game with it off.

I bought this game for co-op. It's awesome. In an age when were seeing less and less couch co-op games, this is really appreciated. Thank you devs for giving me such an amazing experince.

NOTE: (13/03/2016) As of the time of writing this, the PS4 version of this game, however, is unfortunetly broken. Once you get past the beginning stages, it could crash at any time for no reason. It doesn't happen often, but it's annoying as heck. I have yet to hear any word on this being fixed. Darn it. Also, the game seems like it doesn't fit on the screen. I tested the PC version and it doesn't have this problem. It's especially noticeable on the tutorial level. The text is almost totally blocked because it goes off the screen. No word on this being fixed. I would recommend the PC version. I love this game to death, BUT it's unbelievable that ANYONE could release a game on the Playstation store in this state! This problem probably hurt the game more than we know.

I would still prefer playing on my PS4 though, as the crashes aren't often enough to render the game unplayable.

reviewText:
Nuclear Throne is an amazing arcade-style top-down shooter with startling amounts of replayability. It's fast-paced and not once have I been bored in all of my playtime.

The characters are the most colorful and creative I have ever witnessed, which is extremely surprising, considering most of them are simple one-word concepts drawn up as people. Or gods. Or even fish. I don't know how it works, but it does.

The gameplay is perfectly designed; the mutations are really satisfying to pick, and get even more satisying as you get better at the game and actually know which mutations do what.

For those that are iffy on the difficulty of the game, I can say the difficulty is definitely high, but I consider it a large feature of the game. The goal is to reach the Nuclear Throne, and it's not expected of you to do it on your first try, but when you do, (took me 50-60 hours) you will feel so accomplished. Everything in your entire life will light up in stunning clarity, and just as you commence the final fight, ready to take your Nuclear Throne...
you die because you didn't know there was a sudden-death beam at the beginning. you're welcome

But it was worth it, because then you knew it was possible, and you could do it again with an entirely different character, different levels, different guns, and all the same glorious feeling of killing everything in your sight.
It's fun. I promise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm only about 2 hours in at the time of this review, and this is probably the hardest I've ever raged at a video game.

Nuclear Throne is incredibly fast-paced and frantic. It takes time getting used to the sheer amount of chaos happening at once. The game throws you right into the action with no tutorial or simplistic stages. When it comes to figuring out the game, you are pretty much left to your own devices.

This game is also INCREDIBLY HARD. Some enemies shoot out a ruthless spray of bullets, and it only takes a couple of them to kill you. With no recovery time, your character can die within seconds. Fortunately, each stage has a plethora of different weapons lying around, and each one of them has various pros and cons.

Each character has a special move specific to them, from deflecting bullets, to slow motion, to summoning allies for help and so on. This makes each character play very differently, adding to the replayability. Your character also levels up, and can pick from random mutations in order to receive various perks.

With randomly generated levels and level up bonuses the game is endlessly replayable. Which is a good thing, because you will die A LOT. And every death sends you back to the start of the game. And there's no bonuses to make the game any easier when you restart. Nuclear Throne expects you to beat the game all at once, by only using your skills.

The game is still a little rough around the edges, but it has a lot more polish than most other early access games. And it looks like Vlambeer is doing a great job at constantly working on the game.

If you have the money, get this game. It's one of the best (if not the best) twin-stick shooters that I've ever played, even at this stage. Just keep in mind that getting to the Nuclear Throne is far from easy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. It is fun and simple, but it is ungodly difficult at the same time. The premise behind the game is simple. You start the game with two characters, these being Crystal and Fish. All characters have two uniquie things. Their passive and their active. Their passive is just that; an ability that will run in the background, influecing your attack patterns and the drops for players. Their active is also known as their right-click ability. Left-click is the basic attack and the default movement is WASD. Just using the two starting characters as an example, I will show how different playstyles can be from character to character.

Crystal
-Passive: More base health than any other character.
-Active: A temporary shield that will reflect multiple bullets and protect you from others.

Fish
-Passive: Extra ammo recieved
-Active: A dodge roll

Just looking at this, we can see that even the starting characters are different from each other in multiple ways. With Crystal, the game gives you more chances, but it's also easier to get damaged if you aren't paying attention. The shield can be used as a weapon at the same time, however. This will prove useful against specific bosses, such as Big Bandit and Big Dog(the first two bosses in the game). Fish's dodge roll, though not making him invulnerable, can make him extremely aggressive with melee weapons, as he can roll in, attack, then roll out(Optimus Prime appears out of nowhere). And, with Fish, due to his extra ammo passive, you rarely have to ever worry about running out, until you loop, that is.

I won't spoil the entire game, as there are many unlockables and secret areas, but I will tell you this. Before buying this, look up and download Wasteland Kings. Wasteland Kings is the extremely early version of this game, and it will give you a good idea of the insanity that this game will make you go through.

Overall rating: 9/11 Too many explosions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A crazy, hectic, and fun-as-hell top-down shooter! This game doesn't mess around. It throws you right into the action, and you must learn and adapt if you wish to survive.
Despite this game's difficulty level, it is not unfair. With practice, you can learn how to efficiently deal with specific enemies and scenarios that you once thought you would never overcome. Dodging, positioning, and timing are all important skills to develop.
The upgrades system is very simple, but helpful enough to keep things interesting. You can mix and match upgrades to find builds that suit your playstyle. Not to mention all of the unique weapons you can find hidden in the wastelands.

I can be a hothead when it comes to games, but this game does not particularly upset me when I lose. I just try again, and I don't mind trying again because of how enjoyable the game is to play! If the genre interests you, it is definitely worth a try. Especially if you manage to get a 33% off coupon for it!

Early Access Review

One of the few early access game you can trust, and the only one i can trust.
The developers update the game almost weekly, they stream the development, and they are very responsible unlike many other early access developers, they deserve this money.
So now let's actually talk about the game, the game is a 2 dimentional twin shooter rogue like action game that includes some rng (random number generation, or randomness), it has a lot of variation, when it comes to weapons, characters, enemies, levels, mutations and so on...
This kind of game may attract Binding of Isaac fans, Risk of Rain fans and so on.
It can be hard to learn and get into the game, but once you do you won't go back, it's fun, intersting, has many features like daily runs, unlocks and so on, and upcoming features like co-op, new content and so on...
currently the game is not finished but definitely playable, you have a final boss, an ending, even a way to continue after you finished the game, leaderboards so you can race with your friends on the dailys, and remember - it has a lot of replayabillity, and no end - so even if you finish a run you can start another one and it will be different and exciting!

So now let's actually talk about the game, the game is a 2 dimentional twin shooter rogue like action game that includes some rng (random number generation, or randomness), it has a lot of variation, when it comes to weapons, characters, enemies, levels, mutations and so on...
This kind of game may attract Binding of Isaac fans, Risk of Rain fans and so on.
It can be hard to learn and get into the game, but once you do you won't go back, it's fun, intersting, has many features like daily runs, unlocks and so on, and upcoming features like co-op, new content and so on...
currently the game is not finished but definitely playable, you have a final boss, an ending, even a way to continue after you finished the game, leaderboards so you can race with your friends on the dailys, and remember - it has a lot of replayabillity, and no end - so even if you finish a run you can start another one and it will be different and exciting!
ratings:

For an ending i'll say: this game is worthy of your money, the developers are worthy of your money, it has a lot of replayabillity, every run is a whole new experience.
You can also buy it using humble bundle, and you'll get a steam key + a DRM-free copy! plus more money will go to the developers! as well as you can subscribe to their twitch stream and get a channel sub and a steam key.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nuclear Throne is a top down rogue-like shooter set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland featuring animal mutants as the stars of the show. There is some backstory to be had there, but it's out of the way once the game starts up. And boy, is there a game to be had.

Staple to Vlambeer's output, the game features hugely satisfying combat - with shots giving out appropriate amounts of screen shake, freeze frames and audio feedback upon pulling the trigger. You'll learn to love the impact of the shotguns and the sniper like efficiency of the crossbow. The weapons have been given loving amounts of attention, between tweaking, balancing and playtesting there is bound to be something for everyone.

The levels themselves are randomly generated, akin to the way Spelunky or other games of that ilk work. You'll have to navigate through several themed worlds, amassing rads (experience) and weapons along the way. The experience unlocks perks - gameplay perks you'll have to decide upon, the majority of which can greatly shape your playstyle and tactics. Defensive and offensive options abound for the players who like to play safe or for those who need more risk and reward. You'll find yourself on one hand (or two if you're playing Steroids) wielding increasingly massive amounts of firepower, while coping with the snowballing odds. Bands of enemies become hordes, and you'll find yourself in pure glee as you lay waste to everything before your eyes. Nothing can stand between you and victory, noth...oh wait. Death again.

The game is hard, and you'll initially find yourself inching to survive. You'll have to observe individual enemy behaviors, learn to understand the baiting nature of the game, and capitalize on every bit of terrain on the battlefield. With enough time you'll find yourself at the Nuclear Throne...only to loop the game and turn up the difficulty to 11.

The game features, single and local co-op action (still WIP), with dailies to add something to come back to everyday. I await the final release with (fish) baited breath.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has the most ridiculously awesome weapons I have ever seen. You start off with the standard variety of pistols, rifles and shotguns etc. and the developers did a great job of recreating the archetypal behaviour and feel of these familiar guns. The starting weapons do feel a bit underwhelming however, but with enough practice and perserverance, you begin to move deeper into the game, where you are presented with some hilariously over the top futuristic weapons that are very fun and original. For example, the super plasma cannon... Imagine the BFG from Doom, only this time the giant ball of plasma steamrolls over all the enemies, before blowing a huge chunk out of the wall, then splits into several smaller pieces, which fly in all directions and blow additional chucks out of the walls before finally exploding... I won't spoil anymore because one of the most satifying aspects of this game is simply discovering new weapons and trying them out for the first time.

The combat manages to hit that same nerve as old school Nintendo games like Contra or Mega Man, but adds a variety of usable characters, which enable you to develop your own playstyle. There are several different characters to choose from, all with unique abilities, and interesting personalities. At the time of writing, I had put about 60 hours of practice into just one of them, before I finally felt like I had mastered it (literally a fish out of water that smokes cigarettes, plays guitar and dodges bullets by floundering around). My new favourite is a guy who's head is covered in eyes, is telekinetic, but is unable to speak because he doesn't have a mouth, so instead he just mumbles incoherently. He attracts enemies but repels bullets, which is highly effective, and completely changed my approach to the game.

Make no mistake, this game is extremely difficult, but the learning curve is just right and rewards the player through a process of trial and error. Got shot by laser beams? Ok, I'll move out of the line of sight next time. Died to a self-destructing robot? Alright, I'll make sure to stand back when I finish those guys off. Before you know it, you're a pro, and previously difficult sections start to feel routine. That is, until you reach the final boss for the first time and the anxiety gives you a heart attack from the overload of adrenaline...

I haven't had this much fun with a video game for a long time. It makes the rest of my library look sad, and lonely by comparison. If I could choose just one game to have with me on a deserted island, this would be it. Nuclear Throne is an instant classic, and to overlook this title would be doing yourself a disservice.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Choose your music of choice, turn it up to 11, choose your character and enter one of the most gratifying games I've ever played. Nuclear Throne is a game of weapons, mutations and dying. So much dying. While there is a way to end the game without dying you can if you choose to; play the game until you die long past any point of reason. With colourful characters like Fish, Plant and Rebel, fantastical guns such as Grenade Shotgun, Super Crossbow and Laser Minigun not to forget our adverseries, Necromancers, Salamanders and... Lil' Hunter; Nuclear Throne is a game of immense replayability and wonderful fun. Honestly I think if you enjoying shooting things and enjoy a challenge Nuclear Throne is the game for you, it's as simple as that.  I guess I should put down some kind of benchmark for the difficulty. If you found the original Binding of Isaac was a mountain to climb, Nuclear Throne is colonising Mars with a tuna sandwich and some cardboard boxes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before you drop your money on this game you need to be aware of something very, very important about Nuclear Throne: this is probably one of the most difficult and frustrating games you've ever encountered.

I'm not giving this a thumbs-down because the game is terrible, it's a good game.  The graphics are lovely, the music is 10 out of 10, and it is enjoyable to play.  My thumbs-down is not me panning the game, I'm taking the Do you recommend this game?" question literally and writing my review as a warning.  There comes a point when games are so excessively difficult that people need to be notified going in.  There's a very high chance that most people should avoid this game
date: because this game is designed to appeal to an extremely small audience: the highest tier of elite
hoursPlayed: massively-skilled gamers.\n\nIf you want an idea of what you're getting into
voteText: imagine one of the hardest games you've ever played
helpfulPercent: and then imagine if that game sent you back to the very beginning after the slightest mistake.  A bird in Ninja Gaiden knocks you into a pit? Back to level one.  Get hit by a single stray bullet in Contra?  Back to the title screen.  This game is about as difficult as trying to beat Mega Man without getting hit once.\n\nI was aware that this game was difficult when I bought it
votesHelpful: because I love nightmarishly difficult shooters and roguelikes
votesTotal: and this game still was able to alienate me.  You can have a competitive
votesFunny: positive attitude about challenging games
commentsCount: and Nuclear Throne will still transform you into a ragequitter.\n\nThere is no forgiveness
column16: and there is no room for mistakes.  Nuclear Throne demands absolute perfection of you.  And this game doesn't play fair.\n\nYour health bar is pretty much irrelevant
column17: because there are no invincibility frames upon getting hit.  You can have tons of HP upgrades
column18: and a small cluster of bullets will destroy you inside of a split second.  There will always be something far off screen shooting extremely high speed projectiles at you
column19: and your view is very zoomed in.  The screen is always violently shaking
column20: and the game actually mocks you if you turn the screen shake "feature" off
column21: as though your desire to make the game less of a jittery mess is somehow your fault.  Most enemies explode when you kill them. Sometimes it doesn't damage you and sometimes it... does?  Sometimes you'll die being sucked into the exit portal because it spawned next to an explosive object.  Sometimes the game will randomly generate a level where you are surrounded on all sides by enemies with no cover
column22:
and you're dead seconds after the level loads.

You will be saying "what the hell even HIT me?" constantly while playing this game.  Even the best played runs will end because of the tiniest mistake.

I'm certain that the sense of accomplishment upon beating this game is absolute euphoria.  And I'm very certain that there are gamers with superhuman reflexes that this game is like catnip to.  I will say that if you can beat this game
column23: you are truly a phenomenal gamer.  I wouldn't laugh at you if you printed out a screenshot of you beating it and hung it on your wall; you've earned it.  If you are one of those people that is looking for the ultimatest of ultimate challenges
column24: then this game is going to deliver in spades.\n\nBut for the rest of us mortals
column25: I recommend saving your money and your sanity."

reviewText:
Fast, fun, beautifully designed, and brutally unforgiving. On the surface the premise is simple: shoot the things until game over. But dive a little deeper into this colorful world and the details begin to shine. The uniqueness of the characters, enemies, environments, and guns - oh the guns - everything from the satisfying splats of your wasted foes to the taunts of bosses who have crushed you for the 100th time will keep you locked in.

You will die many, many deaths. You will always come back for more.

YOU ALMOST REACHED THE NUCLEAR THRONE...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

More than 350 hours in-game and this game still kicks my ♥♥♥ on a regular basis, so i decided it's time to write a review for this wonderful game.

Despite being one of the hardest games I probably ever played (and maybe will play) i never was that addicted to a game. No matter how far you go and how good you get, there's always new fun and dangerous stuff in your way, more weapon/mutation combos to test out, a character strategy to explore, a new challenge to try and lots more.

You always make new stupid mistakes that didn't happen before, try again, get further, die horribly, try again...
...and again...
...and again...

With weekly updates, two devs streams a week and awesome community forums, this is probably the best game experience I ever had, I have never seen developers with that much dedication towards their project.

This game has still a long way to go (it's Early Access, duh), but even now it is already my favorite top-down shooter of all time.

The sound and the feel of things, the growing hordes of mutant enemies and the crazy, ever-expanding weaponry make this game just... so good.

I don't even know what i like most about this game, the weapons, the enemies, the great community and developers... theres just so much that makes this game perfect.

(also props to you if you read all of this.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really addictive, and rightfully so. This game throws you into action immediately and can just as fast throw you out of it. It's fast, it's unforgiving and it's brutally challenging. It is everything a roguelike game should be.
With a devoted team of developers updates arrive weekly with new features, bugfixing and balancing. Vlambeer also hosts a weekly stream on twitch with development process as well as responding to comments and complains about the game to make sure the audience is pleased with this work in progress masterpiece.
When i first purchased this game i didn't play anything else for a good week or two, not only because there is a lot of ways to play the game (characters, weapons, upgrades etc.) but also because i was driven to see just how far i could get. See when the last boss is defeated you replay the game with the same items and upgrades, only now it's balls to the wall hard. That's where the real difficulty begins.
Being in early access means it just keeps getting better, so i suggest purchasing it now to witness the small changes that improve the game every week. You will hate this game, then you'll love it, then you'll die to that annoying-♥♥♥ enemy and you'll hate it again. But when you loop for the first time and get that sick run with thousands of kills, you'll love it forever.

The uniqueness of the characters, enemies, environments, and guns - oh the guns - everything from the satisfying splats of your wasted foes to the taunts of bosses who have crushed you for the 100th time will keep you locked in.

YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONE
YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONE
YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONE
YOU ALMOST REACHED THE NUCLEAR THRONE...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everything Vlambeer develops ends up turning into gold. This game, even being early access, is my favorite Vlambeer title to date.  Think Hotline Miami meets rogue-like mutant monster infested wastelands. Awesome weapons, mutant upgrade. Gameplay is tight. I love the way the game camera moves. If you don't hold up well with camera shake they give you the option to adjust it under settings. Should also mention the soundtrack is kickass and fits perfect with the game's universe.  Looking back at their history of releases this should be no suprise. Lots of replay value. Good luck surviving long enough to getting to the Nuclear Throne.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have even a passing interest in top-down shooters or roguelites/roguelike-likes, play this game. Even if you don't, I would strongly urge you to consider it anyway. This is one of the most fantastically executed games I have played in my life. Yes, it is in early access, and I will possibly revise this review once the game is fully released (The game currently does not have all the planned content implemented, and there are some bugs and balance issues), but I seriously doubt that my opinion of it will change to anything other than even greater love.
On paper, everything seems pretty swell. The soundtrack is great. The presentation is absolutely incredible. Even the game's setting is very original and oddly intriguing, with a more cartoon-like, but still fairly gritty approach to the post-apocalypse aesthetic, complete with such details as an (admittedly not yet fully fleshed out) original language and hints to some fairly complex plot elements.
In practice though, the game is even better. So, so much better. Nuclear Throne was built from the ground up to be as responsive and as visceral as possible. This is done through many seemingly insignificant factors such as attack animations, sound effects, and screen shake (which can be turned down, but unless you suffer from serious motion sickness, you're doing yourself a disservice by doing so). Combined with the considerable variety of weapons and fairly expansive character roster (both of which are still being added to), this creates a gameplay experience that is absolutely greater than the sum of its parts. Playing Nuclear Throne is enjoyable in ways that descriptions and even gameplay videos can't fully portray, because everything about the game is created to be satisfying on a psychological level.
Also worth noting, the devs everything a independent development can and should ever be. Being in early access, the game is updated around once a week, and the developers are always active on the message boards, receptive to suggestions, and perfectly transparent. Buy the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, this game is very hard. I don't reccomend pcking up the game unless you are an expert at bullet hells. Feel free to try it out even if you don't like shooters, because it is a lot of fun. This game has been in early access for a little over two years, and being almost finished, Nucleaar Throne is getting better and better.
What this game has:
~10 unlockable characters, each with unique gameplay and abilities
~Daily runs to test yur skill against other players for leaderboard highscore
~Over 110 weapons to use
~Looping feature for infinite gameplay
~Bosses, each with a different stragety of killing you
and many more features!
Overall Nuclear Throne is a great game that challenges players to reach the throne over and over again, while also getting better weapons, newer strageties, and dodging skills. Anyway, good luck, and have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey, I have an idea! Let's select our favorite adorably creepy radioactive misfit and take the fight to a meddlesome group of rogues and abominations, all the while loading up on weapons and mutating to adapt to a dystopian hellscape! Sound good? Hell yeah, it does! Oldschool graphics, a soundtrack that inspires the ol' desperado frame of mind, a great variety of characters, weapons and enemies and the ability to mutate with each new level are some of the many perks of fighting your way through a post-apocalyptic wasteland, trying to get yourself a little farther than you got last time!

This is one of those rare games in which you die... A LOT... and yet, it never seems to get on your nerves when you do! It just makes you want to give it one more go! I can honestly say that I've been an exhausted wreck for work on more than one occasion due to wanting one more bid for the throne! ...Whether that's a positive criticism on the game or a negative one for my own sense of priority, I'll have to get back to you on. Point being, this game is highly addictive and an adrenaline rush!

Whether you're looking to spend a day at it, or just kill a few minutes before having to be somewhere, it's an all-around winner! I'd recommend this game like I'd recommend eating food on a regular basis: it just makes sense to do so, and you're ony hurting yourself to contradict! 10/10!

reviewText:
This is the shortened version of my original Slovak review, which can be found here:
http://www.madhouse.sk/152/nuclear-throne
It's a pretty quick traslation, so I apologize if it's not perfect.

Rather than explaining the basic mechanics, I'll only talk about what I personally think is good and bad with Nuclear Throne. Steam won't let me post the full review anyway. If this is still too long for you, skip to the conclusion at the end.

____

Nuclear Throne might seem like a shallow indie title at first...and you could not be more wrong for thinking that. There's a surprising amount of depth, which is the reason why it's still fun to play, after the amount of hours I've put into it.

Even though it is one of those games that I really love, and I do recommend it, it needs to be said that THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. This game is hardcore. Many people claim that it's the most difficult and the most frustrating game they have ever played. SO..if you aren't into rogue-lite and bullet hell, you can stop reading right now. If proceduraly generated content is not your thing, or you are not particularly skilled FPS player (even thought that entire genre), it may be hard for you to really enjoy chaotic nature of Nuclear Throne.
However…if things mentioned above check all your boxes, and you feel strong enough to overcome first several hours full of frustration, then feel free to continue reading.

Organized chaos (the good)

There are many thing that I like about Nuclear Throne. The thing that stands out the most to me is not the sheer amount of content and possibilities, but the way they've tied it all together. The game has many ways how to keep you moving and thinking, and punishes you for every misstep you make. This is the level of depth and that special something"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEven though I've only played like an hour and a half so far, Nuclear Throne is a fun, fast-paced, fun shooter that goes on and on and on until you've reached, the Nuclear Throne. There are a few different characters to use, each having different perks. There's many different guns, each using ammo that you have to pick up. The game goes on to the next level after you kill all the enemies, and if you die, you restart from level 1 or pick a new character. Like I said before, it's a fast-paced, fun shooter that you'll enjoy for a while, even if it's just constant levels. (Also, beware that ESC on your keyboard exits you out of your game when at the main screen!) Plus, the game is only $13, if you're looking for a cheap, but fun game. I'd give this game an 8.8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game off-and-on for a couple of years now and it just keeps getting better. Vlambeer is a great studio and this may be my favorite game in their stellar line-up. Nuclear Throne is a shoot-em-up rogue-like where you battle for the throne in a post-apocalyptic wasteland.

Paul Veers artwork is really something special and just getting to see his designs serves as plenty of motivation to progress to the next stage. There is some great character design in this game. The mutants are colorful, varied and fun.

As it stands, the game is already well worth the price of admission and Vlambeer is just going to keep adding to it as time goes on.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game a while ago and was very skeptical of throwing money at a unfinished game that looked promising but I like many of us have been burned before at the hype and smoke and mirrors style of advertising games have....
I went in skeptical and finished a true believer, this game dudes and ladies, this game is the absolute monkey ♥♥♥♥♥♥ balls to the walls style chaotic shooting role playing experience. now I've hyped it I'll tell you the goods and bads

the awesome.

- The weaponage.
shotguns, machine guns, special weird weapons (laser hammer, flame shotgun, Mini Nuke, semi auto crosbow) , chicken swords and shovels. some balancing needed but good so far

- Variational gameplay.
meaning it's rng. different evertime but sweetly similar, the replayability jumps again at the number of different characters with different styles... I miss the chicken freeze time ability. but consitently you will get better weapons as the game gets harder. none of that binding of issac lame power ups as the game gets harder.

- THE DIFFICULTY.
It's hard, unforgiving like your parents when they caught you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ an apple pie, but that's a good thing because you learn from your mistakes and get better at ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the pie. which makes the expierence all the more rewarding. If you get caught with your pants down it is mainly your own fault

-The Graphics.
that perfect mix of low fi cartoon style but defined well that you can see all the detailed pixel art. there are points that the chaos is too much but that's hardly bad. they got rid of that crappy screen shake problem, and it all flows smoothly, like a waterfall of caramelly chocolate goodness and rainbows wrapped in ♥♥♥♥♥♥s straight into your eyeballs.

- The charaters and Power ups
each character has a unique special ability, all the characters are fun to play and add layers to a already big onion. there's a secret throne room that offers different crowns of game changing awesomeness. after you level you get a moment in the spining vortew to pick a perk that enhances your characters traits. there will always be atleast 2 good power ups for the type of character your building and it's fun to grow stronger as the game does. the difficulty is still tough but unless you can't handle the heat, the food your cookings tasty.

- IT IS FUN
alot of games miss that crucial component. it is fun, I've played alot of this game and it's still fun and I still haven't finished it cause that boss with the jetpack and crazy gun kills me so fast. one moment I'm a mutated fish rolling on the ground the next I'm a mutated fish NOT rolling on the ground. such a powerful image even a child could understand it.
fun, so much fun it's the very definition of fun gameplay

THE ♥♥♥♥

- some small bugs, like the game wont start for me for some updates. but then it does. this is a minor issue and won't matter when they finish it. its still getting better and better. i hope it becomes the masterpiece it could potentially be

- the tips
during loading screens they give you tips, while some like don't die" or "don't be afraid" are funny and even motivating to push yourself further. at some point there should be a deeper guide that you dont have to buy or search for seperately

- the chicken
needs a better power up

in summary buy this game because it's awesome and a great investment in time killing. even now with the early access it's worth twice the asking price.

UPDATE!
I FINISHED THIS MONSTOSITY
conclusion
is 40% learning from mistakes through masochistic dying. 10 % accuracey
date: concentration and dodging 10% concentrated power of will. 40% luck and fun\nno replayability cause it was some guerilla warfare pain."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first glance, the game may look simplistic, possibly even not worth the buy.  But in my opinion, every fan of rouglikes such as FTL, RoR or BoI should have this game in their library.  My playtime can not even reflect the amount of devotion I have poured into this game, but the game gives back.  The sense of achivement, the sense of skill you feel once you beat a certain boss for the first time, or you finally learn how to play a certain character...  it's an amazing feeling.  And what delivers that feeling?  Nuclear Throne.  This is one of my favorite games of all time, and it always will be.  Again, I highly suggest you buy this game.
Thank you for this soul-consuming masterpiece, Vlambeer.  -10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I may or may not have played 77 hours of this game in about four weeks. This game is so refreshing, fun, and unforunately not noticed by many. After watching many videos of this game, I had to get it for myself, and it was simply awesome. I ever appreciated the Top-Down genre, because I don't know why, but the way this game adds Bullet Hell and incorporates updates almost weekly always keeps me interested to come back. Even though I am new to this game, there are so many ideas I have for it, and unlike more popular games, I can freely share them without being embarassed or called out for how ♥♥♥-smearingly stupid it is. I know for a fact that this game company (Vlameer) is very supportive of the community, and always looking for community thoughts and recommendations.

I'd recommend this game to everyone I know, all my friends on Steam, my pet goldfish, and the pilot of this plane that's headed straight towards my house.

That's all. BYE.

reviewText:
I've destroyed bandit clans across the Wasteslands
Conquered the Sewers from rat and gator
Dominated the Scrapyards with an iron fist
Braved the Crystal Caves
Brought heat into the Frozen City
Outmatched Lil Hunter in wits, skill, and firepower
Survived the Labs and its hordes of abominations
Discovered and razed the Palace within seconds
Mastered the weaponary
Became one with the radiation
And stood victorious among wreckage that once was the Nuclear Throne
Only to be bludgeoned to death by a purple ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a stick

10/10

In all honesty, this game is just marvelous. Vicious, gritty, filled to brim with character and challenge and death. Some people may play games as a sort of therapy, but most will need it after wittnessing this masterpiece. Guns upon guns upon guns (with melee weapons), a good selection of classes from a roided-out scientist that can duel wield to a cute little robot that can eat guns for health and ammo. You will rage, you will cry, and you'll come back playing, because when you play Nuclear Throne, you live it. You aren't a person controlling the mutant, you are the mutant. You gain the urges, the lust, and the will to traverse outward on your bloody pilgrimage. To make things right, many must fall, including you, but take heart, and the stars will aline in your favor. Every night by the campfire, every gun you pick up, every foe that drops in your wake is one step closer to reaching...

the Nuclear Throne.
Let's do this.

Edit: It is finally complete and I'm still coming back after a year of playing. I'm suprised to see that fish can still roll.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game off-and-on for a couple of years now and it just keeps getting better. Vlambeer is a great studio and this may be my favorite game in their stellar line-up. Nuclear Throne is a shoot-em-up rogue-like where you battle for the throne in a post-apocalyptic wasteland.

Paul Veers artwork is really something special and just getting to see his designs serves as plenty of motivation to progress to the next stage. There is some great character design in this game. The mutants are colorful, varied and fun.

As it stands, the game is already well worth the price of admission and Vlambeer is just going to keep adding to it as time goes on.

reviewText: After 50 hours with Nuclear Throne I can say with confidence it is worth the purchase. Also, I can say with confidence that I am terrible at it. This game is a bullethell-rouguelike-topdown-twinstick shooter, and it is quite good. The art is nice, and each character is balanced, although each player will end up having a favorite. The gameplay is fast. Really fast. As soon as I die I am left pondering what killed me (thankfully it tells you). You will definitely learn to react quicker and the strategies required to loop throughout your playtime with this game. Daily challenges and weekly challenges keep me coming back, and I love to participate in them. Seeing how I stack up against friends is really fun and I love seeing where I place worldwide (someday I'll be in the top 100 I swear). For the price, it is definitely worth the purchase (also the music is fantastic).

reviewText:
10/10

There is nothing I can say about this game that you can't already find in the countless positive reviews you'll find on this page. The gameplay is responsive and consistently engaging. I haven't even made it all the way through and I love it. The furthest I've reached is 5-3 and I died almost instantly on my first encounter with Lil Hunter. I was devastated that I died. I was overjoyed to have made it that far. I was excited to try again. And that's the best part about this game. No matter how much it kills you, no matter how frustrating it becomes, you never feel like it's impossible. It inspires you to try again and develop better skills. Now, THAT's what makes a great game.

I did not reach the nuclear throne, but at least fish can roll, right?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Northernlion introduced me to Isaac, and I loved it.
Joshscorcher introduced me to TF2, and I adored it.

Bisnap introduced me to Nuclear Throne.
And its my favorite game of all time.

What you have here is a lovely combination of both fast-paced gunplay and roguelike strats into one glorious experience.  In Nuclear Throne, you control one of 11 different, unique mutants and/or other creatures on a never ending quest to reach the titular Nuclear Throne.   Each character has different passive and activatable abilities as well as sometimes unique weapons that make each of them fun to play as.  You have a multi-eyed mutant who can see better in dark levels and use telekinesis to bring enemies and pickups towards him, a literal Melting Man" who has little HP but levels up quicker and can blow up corpses to make stunning chain kills
date: and my personal favorite character is a robot who can eat weapons to gain more ammo or heal itself and can also find better guns earlier.\n\nYou will die in Nuclear Throne.  You always will.  Its simply a matter of when and how.  The game is endless
recommended: with it getting progressively harder each time you "loop" the game.  The entire game is a fight for your life as you race from area to area in the hopes of just seeing the Throne.  On your journey
hoursPlayed: guns and other abilites are not your only ally.  By collecting rods of pure radiation
voteText: you level up and are given access to a selection of 4 mutations from a group of currently over 25.  Each one has viability and can make weapons and/or characters even more fun to play as.  None of them are useless
helpfulPercent: and while some may be more viable overall
votesHelpful: each one has its time and place to be taken.  The weapons are also insane in their own right
votesTotal: ranging from your standard Machineguns
votesFunny: shotguns
commentsCount: and assault rifles
column16: to god-given tools of decimation and absurdity.\n\nThe gameplay theme is conservation
column17: specifically ammo conservation.  Ammo
column18: while obtainable on every stage
column19: is not very common compared to other games.  You can't just fire all you want whenever you want and expect to get the job done.  And while there are melee weapons
column20: even then you have the risk of close-quarters combat with enemies that can crush you before you know it.  This game encourages you to think wisely about what weapons you use and when.  While a crossbow is nice against slow-moving bulky enemies
column21: it isnt good against faster
column22: player-rushing enemies
column23: enemies that an assault rifle would be good for.\n\nEvery run is an adrenaline rush as you make your way through caves and scrapyards in pursuit of the Throne.  And with different layouts
column25: mutations
column26: and characters to recieve and choose from each time
column27: every run is unique.  The soundtrack is also absolutely amazing
column28: a great combination of hardcore rock pieces and somber acoustic guitar songs  that just add on the experience.\n\nIf you have 13 dollars
column34: this is the game to pick up."

reviewText:
Nuclear Throne is a fast and punchy roguelike shooter. It will rock your world, send you back in time before your world was rocked, and will proceed to rock it once more. This cycle will go on forever.
Throwing hard-hitting sound effects, music, and bullets into your face and ears, Nuclear Throne is an endless assault on almost all of your senses.
In the game, you will die not once, not twice, not even thrice. You will die a lot more than that.
You will face challenges that mostly consist of bullets, and you will fail these challenges.

You touch the carpet. Something happens.
You hit Retry and start over.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI decided to pick up this game in the summer of 2013, around when update 34 was implemented. I had followed this game for quite a while but was never able to pick it up until then. I managed to rack up so many hours so fast, that my friends became worried and tried to talk to me about it. I told a few of them to try it out, and now they're addicted to this game. My friends who play it have developed a small cult" and it seems like anyone who listens in on our conversations thinks we are the strangest people. It is now update 95 and so much has changed in this game. I can always find new and interesting ways to get better

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSimultaneously one of the best and most infuriating games I have ever played!
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
TL;DR: BUY THIS GAME.

I really love this game!
It's a fast paced roguelike shooter in which the goal is to get to the 'Nuclear Throne' by advancing through different randomly generated levels. I've only got about 2.3 hours into the game but I play it every day and I love it!
All of the classes are nicely balanced
I love the fact that you can watch Vlambeer's livestreams every Tuesday and Thursday where they add new content
I really like how the game itself is set up!
I bought the predecessor 'Wasteland Kings' in the Mojam 2 Humble bundle, and found out about the improved version at the Indie Developer booth at Minecon :)
I reccomend this game to anyone who has some money to spend on an awesome game!

EDIT: It's been 6 months since I purchased the game and I do not regret it. There was a large gap of time in which I didn't play the game, but a couple of updates put me back into it. I've gotten around 11 hours into this game in 6 months, which isn't really that much because of the length of time that I have owned this game. Even though I'm absolutely horrible at this game and cannot get past Big Dog (the second boss) I still love it to death and won't stop playing it until the development stops on it. The devs really make this game awesome, doing livestreams for players to know that their hard-earned money has not gone to waste, sometimes going onto the livestreams of their community, actually responding to questions on the steam community hub, and doing constant updates. All of this stuff makes me want to play the game, be it because of the new content or just that I'm supporting awesome devs.

EDIT 2: It's been more than a year and a half since I purchased the game. I only have 60 hours in it and suck but it's one of my favorite games. The devs are awesome and the game is great, it's worth your money. I definitely recommend it.

EDIT 3: It's been more than two years since I have purchased this game, it has now been fully released. This game is definitely STILL WORTH IT, and I've enjoyed every minute of my playtime, even if most of my deaths were due to BS like Golden Snow Tanks. Verdict: BUY IT.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome to Nuclear Throne, and this is a review for it. As for now, Nuclear Throne is a early-access rogue-like indie game, that receives weekly updates to make the game more balanced and fun, as well as adding a lot of stuff. It still has loads of planned features, so if you decide to get the game, stick around it for a while, or come back to it from times to times to always have new experiences with it.

Now starting from the game: You open the game to be welcomed by a very enjoyable soundtrack, as well as the character selection menu for it. You start the game with a few characters, but as you progress through it, you will unlock more of them, and at the time of this review, they are pretty easy to unlock. Every character has a passive and active ability, the active ability being used by pressing the right button of the mouse once in-game. It's also recommended you try every character, since they all play differently.

Once you select a character, you are ready to go. You will find yourself with a weapon at hands, surrounded by enemies in the middle of a nuclear wasteland. Your objective is to use the weapons and abilities on your arsenal to kill all the enemies in the area to activate a portal, leading to the next level. You quest is to reach a throne, collecting radiation on your way to mutate yourself and turn into a even more powerful being, as well as collecting new weapons, which can be divided by:
-Bullet weapons
-Shell weapons
-Bolt weapons
-Explosive weapons
-Energy weapons
-Melee weapons
(note that all the weapon types listed above have their own ammo, and also their own sub categories, but that use the same ammo type)

The gameplay is very simple. You spawn in a area, filled with enemies, and the random generated levels could get you easily, so keep an eye open. Sometimes it could be very easy but in other occasions, it might just swarm you with foes, leaving you to die right after spawning. The game can also be frustrating at the time, since the chances of you being a master right off the start are very small, so you can expect to die a lot, but it's all part of the game, everytime you play it and die, you grow better at it for learning how to deal with enemies carefully. Keep an eye on your ammo, as you might run out pretty quickly with certain weapons, and don't forget to choose your mutations wisely.

Wrapping everything up, I'd give Nuclear Throne a 10/10 for being an awesome game. Awesome soundtrack, challenging gameplay, and an frustrating, yet enjoyable, expirience. I'd recommend going to the game's Wiki[nuclear-throne.wikia.com] for more in-depth information about the game's development and already implemented features. Remember once again that the game might not be enjoyable right away for some people not used to this kind of game, rogue-likes tend to be difficult and require patience to play and master

reviewText: So this game plays a lot like both Hotline Miami and Binding of Isaac.\nFirst off you start as a measly level 1 mutant with a revolver, a special ability, and a thirst for plutonium and more power. The levels, loot, and enemies are all randomly generated, with set bosses at certain points. Get enough plutonium and you'll level up and get to pick one of four random new mutations (more ammo capacity, more melee range, some kills generate HP, and so on). When you die, it's game over. You will die a lot, and you will keep saying to yourself Just one more time......" over and over again."

reviewText:
Amazing RPG/Rogue-like indie title.
Several  different characters, perks and randomized levels that will keep one busy for a while.
There are some resemblances with Isaac, but i would say this one, picked up where Isaac left off.
NT has much more pace and  action packed.
Everything feels so polished, well thought and entertaining.
It should not let anybody down for sure, letalone fans of the genre.

爽快感と達成感が凄まじいカオスなゲーム。メチャクチャ。ヒャッハー！！ってなる。
敵がウジャウジャ出てくるし、色んな所から攻撃が来る。
地形や敵、武器なんかもランダム生成なので結構、運が絡んでくる。
ヤられて徐々に武器の扱いや立ち回りを覚えていく。
ぶっ飛んでるゲーム。楽しい。そして、難しい。

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is outrageously addictive. Elements from the Binding of Isaac, Hotline Miami and Borderlands combine to make an extremely challenging but fun game that you will play for hours on end trying to get past the next area. Good variety of different characters, weapons, mutations and enemies keep this bullet-hell roguelite new and refreshing every time. Loads of content for an early access game and more polish than most full releases. Would recommend more than any other game i've been playing recently.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is bad to the bone. I enjoy the soundtrack and the mutations are a fun leveling tree. This game is tough. I would like to see online multiplayer. My only complaint so far has been that in local co-op the descriptions of stuff, such as your base traits and what the mutations will do, overlap and cut one player off from seeing their description properly.

I have also noticed that it seems significantly easier in singleplayer than in multiplayer (though still hard as crap-for me anyway). I'm not sure if that means that me and my friend suck, if multiplayer is not ideal for this crazy fast paced small level game, or what.

Regardless of any flaws, this game is awesome. I paid full price and it was totally worth it. I highly recommend it, as long as you are prepared to die a ton.

Early Access Review

This is of course a game, but its more special than any game by 1 aspect only , and it makes this game extremly different than almost any game you will ever play. I will summerize the whole deal in 3 words.
Hardest - Game - Ever.
Even our society's best Faze clan's 360 no scopers will have a very hard time going through different generated levels.
The game's content makes it a very fun game even though its hard, lots of different weapons and classes and upgrades, different monsters and enemies, each level is different than the other one. Basically , you can't get bored of this game realy...
I recommend this game to anyone who seeks challenge in gaming. If you beat this game , you are the true Matrix - Illumnati - Faze clan - xXx_swag360noscoper_xXx.""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

More unforgiving than dark souls and the most rage inducing game i've ever played. Makes me want to strangle children.

Great game, 10/10

But on a serious note, the game is truly amazing. Ever since I bought it when it first came out, it's been a great deal of fun experiencing the new updates and growth of the game. The delevopers roll out new updates every sunday (don't quote me on the day) with detailed patch notes, bug fixes, and new content.

In my opinion, what makes this game stand out is it feels like an arcade game. You can pick it up and play it whenever you want without a commitment to a large amount of time.

Although the learning curve is somewhat steep, the first time you loop the game is a very rewarding feeling.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Indie game of the year 2015. Sorry Undertale, you have heart and story, but this game has raw replayability.

One of the best roguelites I've ever played. You don't have to reset endlessly for a viable run, enemies actually die when you shoot them, and...just in general, it's a joy to play. It's punishing as hell, but it's fast, the gunplay is amazing (Borderlands doesn't have ♥♥♥♥ on the weapons in this game) and only the most frustrating deaths will dissuade you from taking explosive revenge.

It's also worth noting that it's one of the most exemplary titles in Early Access and it won't go on sale until after release, so if you're curious, go for it now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Extremely fast-paced shooter where you have to keep track of everything going on and brace yourself for bullet hell.

You play as one of 10 characters (more are being added), all with different abilities. The range of abilities paired with the different weapons and player mutations enables you to try many different playstyles until you find one that suits you.
Some of the characters have melee weapons other have ranged weapons, all with different properties.

Most of the gameplay is running around quickly in a small arena trying to kill all the enemies in order to get power-ups, ammunition & new weapons. Between the randomly generated levels your character gains mutations which are different perks applied to your character.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nuclear Throne is a fast paced top-down shooter with rogue-like elements.

It takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where everything is out to get you, including crows with SMGs and rats. So many rats.

This game is pretty hard but obviously the more you play the better you get and also the more knowledge you obtain to better your next run. There is a vast amount of weaponry from average pistols to poison grenade launchers and rifles that literally shoot lightning.

An average Nuclear Throne run looks like this:
To start, there is a flurry of bullets coming towards you. As you continue, you get better weapons but the enemies get stronger and shoot MORE bullets towards you. Every few levels, you find a boss that has considerably more health than everyone else, and seem to only spawn when you are in a pinch and surrounded by enemies.

In short, this game has a surprising amount of story to it and the developers update it almost every week, not to mention the music is awesome and there are secret levels everywhere. What more could you ask for?

Early Access Review

Within an hour, Nuclear Throne became my all time favorite game. Having over 200 games on Steam and having played many more on handhelds, consoles, and yes, even phones, I can safely say that this game is worth thirty times what it costs as of now.

Let's start with the gameplay. Oh, the gameplay. Every gun is varied and somewhat useful and satisfying to use, the characters and how you play them vary vastly despite having little differences between them, And by satisfying, I mean oh, good lord. Let me quantify this. Have you ever played a game in which a shotgun feels the same as a pistol? That game lacks what some call, crunch". Nuclear Throne is naught but crunchy. Killing with the basic revolver is satisfying if a bit difficult

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Review is based on Update # 59)

Fast paced twitch shooter combined with a rogue-like. Very challenging game with most deaths can happen before you realize what is going on but a single run shouldn't take more than an hour. Developers are constantly updating the game which is great and despite being in early access, the foundation is really good.

The only problems are that the game doesn't have that progression or replayability of another action/rogue-like game: The Binding of Issac. Despite procedurally generated levels, there isn't enough difference between runs to make them stand out in terms of new enemies, situations etc. But what's in the game so far is good and it can only get better from here.

reviewText:
Please stay away from this game. It will take over your life. I've sunk 67 hours into this thing and I've only now looped it ONCE.
It's really ♥♥♥♥ing hard, and it will completely win you over with its superb soundtrack, INCREDIBLE sound design, colourful cast of characters and that signature Vlambeer screenshake.

The guns have an incredibly satisfying punch to them, you'll never get tired of shooting them. And you'll be doing a whole lot of shooting.

If you enjoy dying over and over and over and shooting a whole lot of guns, then maybe the game is for you!

You'll die a lot though!

Dying means restarting the whole thing!

But I mean if you have the patience for dying and restarting, there's a whole lot to do in the game. Like incredible amounts of things to discover and unlock. Fun things! Cool things! Very silly things! Secret endings! Daily and weekly challenges! Leaderboards!

And a lot of dying!

Don't say I didn't warn you!

Great game, would die again 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game just might overtake The Binding of Isaac as the best modern roguelike. Not as many items and mutations as that game but the raw gameplay is skill based and more akin to Hotline Miami as opposed to BoI where it's all about your items and bullet-hell running around. It has a wild-west feel of emptying your clip and hoping that when the dust settles you'll be alive and there'll be enough supplies for the next level.

The story, setup, worlds, bosses, guns, enemies, and artstyle are top notch. Every time you die it never feels like the game screwed you, and each world has it's own tactics and style.

Just a perfect game and a truly unique roguelike. My only complaint so far is that they need to add more characters. 7 doesn't feel like enough for this game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
this game is good as heck

it's got the action, it's got that replay value, all the upgrades are good and despite some not being just '+health' or '+damage' they all have meaningful impacts on play.

the game's mechanics are pretty nice, there's always RNG involved but there's ways to be smart about what you pick so that you can set yourself up for better stuff

Weapon combinations matter and what character you use them on matter. every character has their own thing going for them, and different upgrades are going to be better for different characters. Some guns you get from the start can last you a while, and it's pretty rare for your weapons to become 'outdated' if you manage your drops wisely and pick the right mutations.
Enemies are kind of odd sometimes, and you're going to feel legitimately cheated sometimes when you turn the corner and a flock of enemies rip you a new everything. The game is fast to restart though, and you'll be getting shot by crows again in no time.
The action from fight to fight goes from calm and controlled to frantic and twitchy very quickly, and the fear factor of losing a good setup really helps with the panic of being on low health and surrounded. Some times you'll just die, but other times you manage to kill off a filled room at 1 health and it feels great.

These devs update once per week. There is always something these two want to update with the game, and the updates bring new guns, UI, balance, upgrades, everything. This is an Early Access title where you can really see where your money's going. The devs keep up to date with the community and it's pretty much amazing. Only a slight downside, but you do have your save reset every update. Characters aren't hard to unlock though, and it takes about an okay life or two to unlock all but one of the characters, the last one being a bit trickier to unlock carelessly.

Over time, you'll start to understand the game more and really come to love some of the possible loadouts and character setups you can pull off in this game.

DO NOTE, HOWEVER, if you can't spend the sub-20-or-something dollars this game costs, it's not going on sale until the game is completely finished. Get less than 20 dollars. This is a good game.

6/10 there's mimics

EDIT NOW THAT IT'S OUT: Yeah still get this game. Just like before, only get it if you're a real hardcore video gamer who plays tough video games that hurt to lose at.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You did not reach the Nuclear Throne.

You shall see the above text hundreds, maybe thousands of times before getting past the first three zones.

But the lure of the Throne is a Siren's Song you cannot ignore. Yes, your life is hard. Still, you must try.

The Throne is all that keeps you going. Can you find it? Will anyone ever find it? No one has touched it since...

But what of the world that used to be? There used to be trees here. The air was once clean, waters once clear.

Your gruelling journey will only ever end with the sitting upon the Throne, if the Legends prove true.

The only hope you can have true faith in now is the Throne. Somehow, deep down, you know.


The Throne definitely exists.

The fluid nature of the game will keep you guessing and playing for hours, without you realizing that any time has passed at all. The controls are intuitive and feel so good. I love this game a lot, just because the concept is great, and the execution was masterful. The game is simple enough so that you know what's being thrown at you, but clever enough to not be predictable. The soundtrack and atmosphere have me falling in love with a wasteland. My thoughts are kind of incoherent, due to the fact my brain is screaming Stop writting this review right now and get back to playing the game."

Basically

reviewText:
What is Nuclear Throne? What is expenses? Could it be possible that ancient civilizations were visited by outer space travelers? Let's find out.

Nuclear Throne is an isometric bullet hell shooter with roguelike elements. Esentially, the goal of the game is to clean seven 'worlds' or instantiations of a nuclear wasteland by killing every moving thing in them. To do so, you are armed with a broad range of weapons, from classic assault rifles and revolvers to more futuristic stuff like laser cannons and lightsabers. Also, your character mutates as you kill more enemies, obtaining certain buffs like extra health, lower enemy bullets, the ability to push through walls, etc.

From the first moment it is clear that the game has a very arcadey setting. Lots of bullets, screen shaking constantly, low health both for the player and the enemies. Some enemy faking death gets up and instakills you. A boss spawns right next to you. A cop reflects your bullets back, killing you in the process. In Nuclear Throne, everything happens very fast, especially your death. This is a hard game. This is the most important thing to bear in mind when purchasing Nuclear Throne. It is a ♥♥♥♥ing hard game. And I'm not talking about Dark Souls-like hard. If you're ok with dying against the easiest enemy, for any bad decision, for any second of doubt, then go ahead and buy the game. Otherwise go buy any PS3-gen game.

As mentioned above, Nuclear Throne has some roguelike elements, namely random level generation and permadeath. The former is well implemented, although in a simple way. Most levels have nothing remarkable about them. Some people complain about spawning in the middle of a room full of enemies. It is true that some spawning scenarios may be overwhelming at first, but in my experience I have found that it is possible to deal with this situations. Regarding permadeath, there's not much to say in a time when every indie roguelike has permadeath because it is trendy.  You can argue that it is a way to artificially extend the game life, you can argue that its a way of mastering the game. That's up to you.

The setting of the game is pretty bizarre. You find yourself in an unexplained nuclear wasteland, where the survivors fight for some reason not really clear, but who really cares about lore in a arcade shooter? Most of the characters and enemies are mutated animals, which is quite original. The art of the game is simple but effective, and matches the tone of the game. The music is amazing, go check it out for yourself (the ♥♥♥♥ing ending song dude, the ♥♥♥♥ing ending song).

Nuclear Throne comes with some very welcome features like many playable characters with different strong and weak points and lots of different weapons, which leads to different gameplay styles. There are crowns, which act as game modifiers, and also some secret levels. Recently, daily and weekly challenges were added. Not that they are a completely different game, but these things add some replayability.

In conclusion, Nuclear Throne is one of the best roguelike games right now. If you like the genre, and don't mind dying a lot while slowly getting better, then this is your game. And, by the way, yes, aliens built the pyramids. You said it. Not me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You did not reach the Nuclear Throne.

You shall see the above text hundreds, maybe thousands of times before getting past the first three zones.

But the lure of the Throne is a Siren's Song you cannot ignore. Yes, your life is hard. Still, you must try.

The Throne is all that keeps you going. Can you find it? Will anyone ever find it? No one has touched it since...

But what of the world that used to be? There used to be trees here. The air was once clean, waters once clear.

Your gruelling journey will only ever end with the sitting upon the Throne, if the Legends prove true.

The only hope you can have true faith in now is the Throne. Somehow, deep down, you know.


The Throne definitely exists.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Indie game of the year 2015. Sorry Undertale, you have heart and story, but this game has raw replayability.

One of the best roguelites I've ever played. You don't have to reset endlessly for a viable run, enemies actually die when you shoot them, and...just in general, it's a joy to play. It's punishing as hell, but it's fast, the gunplay is amazing (Borderlands doesn't have ♥♥♥♥ on the weapons in this game) and only the most frustrating deaths will dissuade you from taking explosive revenge.

It's also worth noting that it's one of the most exemplary titles in Early Access and it won't go on sale until after release, so if you're curious, go for it now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Within an hour, Nuclear Throne became my all time favorite game. Having over 200 games on Steam and having played many more on handhelds, consoles, and yes, even phones, I can safely say that this game is worth thirty times what it costs as of now.

Let's start with the gameplay. Oh, the gameplay. Every gun is varied and somewhat useful and satisfying to use, the characters and how you play them vary vastly despite having little differences between them, And by satisfying, I mean oh, good lord. Let me quantify this. Have you ever played a game in which a shotgun feels the same as a pistol? That game lacks what some call, crunch". Nuclear Throne is naught but crunchy. Killing with the basic revolver is satisfying if a bit difficult
date: most of your friends will find differing opinions on characters to use
hoursPlayed: the game's FUN. No questions asked

reviewText:
I won't debate over what could the game have been if worked on more, with more content or whatever.

I actually think that it is one of the best twinstick shooter-action rogue-like and one of the best, let's simply say, action game of all time. I'm speaking of game pleasure, enjoyement sec per sec. It's amazing how, to me at least, the game provides raw fun and addiction.

I can't really explain why, is it because of its elegant simplicity but vicious difficulty ?

Or the perfect feeling of power into a fragile body that can go anywhere but still die at every moment ?

Or the fact that everything felt like into my control when I control nothing ?

Or maybe because you fall into a repetitive mechanic of doing the same things but always different ?

Hard to say, but I think that the secret of this game lies into a perfect balance of things.

It's true alchemy.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Nuclear Throne is an addictive rougelike with procedurally generated levels. Even though the game is insanely difficult, and at first you might feel like you regret purchasing this game, it grows on you a lot and you eventually get better. You will die all the time, a lot, again and again, yet you will want to play more and more. This game starts out as very obscure, you will learn things the hard way and eat drit and ♥♥♥♥ from bosses and hordes of enemies alike.

As you progress from level to level you earn experience, which you can then spend on random upgrades. This makes each run uniqe and unpredictable, adding up to replayability. This game offers more in terms of progression, like new characters, ♥♥♥♥ ton of weapons, crowns and etc..

~Not sure if Nuclear Trone for you?~

Well if you like bullet hells, rougelikes, a good challange, variability, top down shooters and a bit of unpredictability, it definitely is! And even if you don't like any of the following consider this; for the price it asks it's an amazing game and it could be a good starting point if you are interested in this genre of games, it was mine too and I'm enjoying it a lot. It feels good to shoot enemies on the screen, devs polished this game to perfection, and despite of it's difficulcity, it's still managable, you just need to get better at it. Though if you get frustrated easily, are impatient and you consider yourself a causal gamer, or someone who doesn't like steep learning/skill curve, you should probably avoid this.

Also the music is just soooooooooooooooooooooo good. Especially first sewer levels. Great work by Kozilek! It shapes the overal atmosphere of this game, making it an unlikely great gaming experience.

All in all, highly reccomended.
