reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI expected this game to be fun, but I've actually been enjoying it even more than I expected.  Games with roguelike elements are known for their high replayability, and Nuclear Throne is no different, but a big part of the replay value in this game is the different abilities of each of the characters.  Transform into an immobile bullet-reflecting cyrstal spire, eat guns and recycle them into ammunition, ensnare enemies in a tangle of thorny vines, cause enemy corpses on screen to explode... each character changes your approach to the game in sometimes subtle and sometimes dramatic ways, and that'sone of the big things that keeps me coming back.  Even though I do have my personal favories... Robot and Melting 4 life!  And death.  Lots and lots of death.

Early Access Review

Jesus ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ing CHRIST is this game good. Vlambeer, you've outdone yourselves once more.

PROS:
-Balls to the wall difficult
-A ♥♥♥♥ ton of replay value, maybe even more than Isaac
-An epic soundtrack with a mix of hard rocking songs and mellow melodies
-A disgusting amount of weapons (Although, some of them suck.. -coughtoxiccrossbowcough-)
-Plenty of upgrades that allow you to tailor the game to your tastes

CONS:
-Still in beta, which means the game isn't nearly as good as it will be
-Low number of characters

All in all, this game is beyond good. If you like Touhou, Hotline Miami, or Isaac, you should pick this game up right away. Also, if this game goes on sale, I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ if you can barely afford food, YOU BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI expected this game to be fun, but I've actually been enjoying it even more than I expected.  Games with roguelike elements are known for their high replayability, and Nuclear Throne is no different, but a big part of the replay value in this game is the different abilities of each of the characters.  Transform into an immobile bullet-reflecting cyrstal spire, eat guns and recycle them into ammunition, ensnare enemies in a tangle of thorny vines, cause enemy corpses on screen to explode... each character changes your approach to the game in sometimes subtle and sometimes dramatic ways, and that'sone of the big things that keeps me coming back.  Even though I do have my personal favories... Robot and Melting 4 life!  And death.  Lots and lots of death.

reviewText:
Original review posted in: 5 Nov, 2014 @ 8:48pm with 18h of gametime.

Now im 131h in and with most of the achievements.

I am in love with this game, its something that you can just play for an hour or two, play something else and come straight back to without the need to learn new things or *warm up* again.

Pros -
Vast array of weapons and enemies
Well done art style
Challenging Achievements
Lots of levels and secrets
Easy to learn but hard to master
A large selection of characters
Daily runs
Weekly runs that have a challenge with them

Cons -
Most runs can be decided entirely be RNG, Some times you will spawn into a level and be swarmed with enemies that will practicaly inta kill you.

Considering this game? Just buy it, this game is well worth the money and in my eyes should cost more than it does. It runs well, fun and rewards you when you get good at it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**PLEASE KEEP IN MIND THIS WAS WRITTEN 10/26/13 AND AS THIS GAME IS IN BETA IT IS CONSTANTLY CHANGING SO THIS REVIEW IS BASED ON THE GAME AS IT WAS AT THE TIME**

Yet another addicting roguelike from Vlambeer and friends, Nuclear Throne is the cooler older brother of Super Crate Box. This time around there are more crazy monsters to kill with another massive arsenal and seven new playable characters to do it with. When I first saw previews for the game, I recognized the work immediately as Vlambeer, as I was a huge fan of Super Crate Box. One of the most enjoyable aspects of this game is being able to move freely through an open level, opposed to the single screen of SCB as well as the option to choose from multiple characters with different stats and special abilities.

After a few failed attempts at trying to reach out to Vlambeer via Twitter for a possible copy to review I just decided to buy it. Supporting indie developers like Vlambeer who have provided us gamers with awesome free games like Super Crate Box doesn’t bother me, I just didn’t want to wait till my next payday to be able to play this game, AND coincidentally Nuclear Throne happened to come out on my birthday. Anyway, I digress… Nuclear Throne is more fun than playing Mario 3 christmas morning 1988 and manages to keep you on your toes while you battle through each level where your goal is to clear it of all enemies. Loaded with upgrades, tons of different weapons and ammo, a boat load of monsters that came off a zombie infected Noah’s Ark of doom, and a cast of characters resembling the Garbage Pail Kids, Nuclear Throne is sure to turn you into the next Toxic Avenger.

Nuclear Throne is Vlambeers latest action roguelike-like about mutants fighting their way through a post-apocalyptic world. The radioactive waste in the world allows mutants to get ahead by mutating new limbs on the fly, the abundant availability of powerful weaponry makes the quest to become ruler of the Wasteland one fraught with peril. At this point in development, Nuclear Throne consists of 7 playable characters and has 4 worlds, each containing 3 sub levels that you must complete before moving on to the next. Your ultimate goal is to clear the map, collect ammo, build your arsenal and gather nuclear waste to gain levels.

To gain levels you must collect the nuclear waste capsules that enemies drop after you kill them. After collecting so many of these you gain your next level and given the opportunity to upgrade your character. Some of these upgrades include “Lucky Shot” that when added allows some shots to regenerate ammo. “Blood Lust” gives you the ability where some kills may regenerate your HP, or “Rhino Skin” which gives you an added +4HP. These upgrades are essential to your gameplay, and if you choose wisely you can get further and further every time you play.

The gameplay of Nuclear Throne is genius and compelling, keeping you glued to your computer making every last bullet a battle cry at redemption. Each character has its own special ability and varied stats, for example, “Fish” gets more ammo than most other characters, and his special ability is the doge roll. Whereas “Crystal” gets more HP, and has the crystal shield as a special ability. Right now my favorite character is “Plant.” He moves around faster, and has the ability to throw seeds out and snare enemies making it easier to kill them. This helps greatly when trying to move around enemies that are shooting at you as well, not to mention snaring larger enemies allowing for an easier target to move around.

Weaponry isn’t an issue when it comes to Nuclear Throne. Everything from a screwdriver to a grenade launcher, Vlambeer certainly didn’t leave anything out of this one. The shooting dynamics when using a mouse and keyboard are flawless, and put the power from your current weapon at your finger tips. Extra ammunition is found from killing enemies and dropped randomly, usually when you’re running low. Like many roguelikes, ammo is essential and there usually isn’t that much of it readily available, especially when using the triple machine gun.You can also find ammo and extra weapons from the chests scattered throughout each level, and health is also dropped this way as well.

The music in Nuclear Throne blends perfectly with gameplay and isn’t overly annoying like in most other games. I liked that each level had its own unique and distinct music that was congruent to its surroundings. Graphicly, Nuclear Throne is a step up from Super Crate Box and adds more shading while adding more characteristics to the enemies and playable characters. Overall, Nuclear Throne is an awesome game, tons of fun to play, and leaves you wanting more. Anytime that I find myself thinking about a video game outside of my house I know that its a hit. Needless to say this game is incredible, and even in early development shows promise. I highly suggest this one, its bound to be another classic.

Graphics: 7/10
Playability: 7/10
Story: 3/10
Challenge: 7/10
Replay Value: 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is Nuclear Throne?
------------------------------------

A hectic bullet-hell battle to reach the fabled Nuclear Throne." Fight through levels of deadly enemies that can and will kill you on sight. Shoot maggots with a Triple Machine-gun or use a crossbow on a bandit while avoiding hundreds of bullets that will chunk your health down pretty quickly.

The cast of characters is vast and their abilities add a new type of playstyle everytime you try them out. Playing "Melting" lets you explode every corpse you create
date: but you only get 2 health. That's basically a one-hit wonder. Play as "Crystal" and block and reflect every shot for a limited time
recommended: but be careful not to get surrounded. Play as "Steroids" and get a hefty amount of health and dual-weilding capacity. Ever wanted to shoot double laser guns? I know I have.\n\nThis game will keep you entertained and hitting R to quick restart for a good amount of time every session. The levels are randomly generated
hoursPlayed: and so are the enemies
voteText: but the difficulty never goes down. Gather experience to gain upgrades such as an increase in melee range or regenerating bullets on hit.\n\nIf you manage to reach the Vault
helpfulPercent: you can gain a Crown upgrade that may make the game more rewarding
votesHelpful: but also challenging. You could also choose no crown
votesTotal: for a bald head is the best head.\n\nWhether you're a casual gamer or a bullet hell lover
votesFunny: this game will manage to keep you entertained for it's value

not to mention Vlambeer likes to release constant updates fixing bugs and adding content.

reviewText:
rating: worth buying at full price
score: 8/10 - very good
similar games: Doom, Binding of Isaac
tags: shooter, rogue-lite, top down

Nuclear Throne is one of those games which have great core gameplay, but lack content and maybe a bit polish too. Because of that the game didn't provide a satisfying experience to me although the gunplay is really satisfying. What I basicly expect from every rogue-lite game these days is the following:

lots and lots of unlockables -> encourages multiple playthroughs and makes death not feel meaningless
The only unlocks in Nuclear Throne are new characters, but those I would normally count as a bonus, since they don't affect your next playthrough at all, they just offer a new playstyle, but if you don't like most of the characters then these unlocks are worthless to you. And that was the case a bit for me in Nuclear Throne. Some of the characters are useless if you ask me, but the most fun to play character was definitly Steroids, and I just play as him. He has the highest DPS and is just the most crazy character which makes him by far the most fun to play for me. But at least the character design is really creative and cool. You can also unlock crowns but they are useless and don't have a big impact on the game, and you can unlock golden weapons which replace your starting weapon, which isn't a big deal, because you get new and good weapons really fast anyway.

lots of different upgrades -> makes every run feel more unique
There are only a handful of upgrades (mutations are they called) in this game and a third of those are completely useless. Because of that your character build will be same more of less for every run. Also there is a mutation which heals you when you make kills, this is BY FAR the best mutation in the game and has a too big impact on the game. This wouldn't be a problem if the HP drops weren't so random. In some runs the game is generous and gives you lots of HP drops, in other runs you will rarely see one. What is the point in this extreme randomness?

randomly generated levels need things which are worth randomly generating -> make every run feel more unique
What I mean by this is how similar the runs feel because of how the levels are generated. The enemies you encounter for every region will be the same, the types of weapons you will find will be same, just the paths you have to go will be a bit different but the difference won't have any impact on how you will play the levels, they are just different so the game isn't completely the same every time. But this is not enough. In very few instances sometimes a rare enemy appeared in a level. This game needs more of that, don't have a set ensemble of enemy types per region and use them all, but have a big pool of enemies per region and only use a few of that pool, so you will encounter different enemies every run. The weapon drops could also use more variety. Maybe give weapons status effects like burn of freeze damage (that exists in the game but just a bit).

the game needs to become harder after every playthrough -> encourage multiple playthroughs and allows the developers to better balance the learning and difficulty curve
What I mean by this is how Binding of Isaac does things. For your first run there are only like 6 regions, when you beat the final boss you permanently unlock a new region after the final one for your next run which is more difficult. Then you unlock another region maybe, but then after beating the main boss 10 times the whole game gets more difficult, but that also makes sense because by this point you have unlocked tons of items and upgrades. Nuclear Throne has the looping" mechanic and hard mode
date: but that's it.\n\nAnother thing which is extremely infuriating in this game is how sometimes you can be nothing but unlucky and just die
recommended: especially in 5-3 where you sometimes spawn in the middle of million enemies while a boss appears which shoots 100 projectiles
hoursPlayed: flys all over the places while making explosions when landing
voteText: spawning more enemies AND when you beat him he will randomly fly in a direction and explode. You beat the boss but because RNG decided to make him fly in your direction and explode you loose anyway. There are lots of really cheap deaths like that in the game. Even more infuriating is when a portal spawns near a car and make the car explode which can kill you even if you have lots of HP. And the thing is I don't understand why this is
helpfulPercent: because apart from these cheap things the enemy design is GREAT with a lot of variety and depth.\n\nOne last thing. The game's core gameplay is already really good and has depth
votesHelpful: but it could have even more depth by allowing the player to carry more than 2 weapons. I think it would be great if you just could carry a weapon of each weapon type at the same time. This is would give the game more depth because then you would have to consider more criteria when making more decisions. reviewText:
Nuclear Throne is a fun and frantic top-down shooter rogue-lite in which you must defeat the Nuclear Throne with any of its interesting characters and multitude of weapons however it's rife with game ending problems at the moment.

Pros + Frantic top-down action shooter rogue-lite.
+ Multiple characters each with a unique active ability and ultra-mutations. If one doesn't fit your play style, simply choose another.
+ Fun mutation system, sometimes you get ones you don't want but have to make it work.
+ Interesting to infuriating enemies (I'm looking at you scorpions, rats, flame traps and green ooze exploder).
+ Multitude of weaponry, some good, some bad, some great and some awful.
+ Daily and Weekly Challenges ideas are great.
+ Crown system for run manipulation.

Cons - The game is prone to the occasional crash.
- Still has a lot of bugs that should've been fixed before release, but alas the devs had to honour a contractual agreement on PSX and it would've seemed strange that it released on platform and not the other I guess.
- Base weapon RNG is just terrible. The frequency at which you get duplicate weapons is way too high (but then again it's random).
- Level generation leaves A LOT to be desired. Sometimes it's good and other times you get swarmed with no way out. The player should always spawn in a safe location and not right next to enemies as it currently does as this often leads to panic and death.
- Some boss fights rely on your initial spawn namely Raven\Assassin + Sniper infested Big Dog fight and Tank + Snow Bot\Yeti Lil' Hunter fight.
- Most Crowns seem rather pointless or worthless as they make your run worse with no added benefits.
- The Daily Challenge is not really fair or balanced as players can choose whichever character to play as and certain characters are just better overall. Secret levels, big weapons chest and leveling right before a level has a tendency of changing the seed resulting in a modified level generation. Crowns especially Crown of Blood can have an unfair advantage on score (but this is more like Ghosting in Spelunky so I'm not too peeved about it, if you're good enough to do it then do it).
- Speaking of Daily and Weekly Challenges, their leader boards have been broken since release. I know the devs are working on it but it should've been ready at launch.
- Hard Mode is just terrible and not fun. The game basically starts on Loop 1, 1-1 and the player is given a big weapons chest at the start which contains 'beginning tier' weapons to deal with  swarms of enemies. I get that Hard Mode was put in as a joke but that is most certainly not how you do hard mode.

Irritations - Each character starts off with the same gear, a pistol except Chicken and Rogue. Even though you can unlock golden weapons to start off with, I'd have liked if each character had a different base starting weapon.
- Enemies know your position as you spawn even without line of sight and often shoot at you from off-screen.
- Enemy AI is too inconsistent at times; Bandits will often look at you and shoot backwards or vice-versa. Yeti bots can be stuck in their charge state for a very long time often gliding across the levels. Snow dogs can be stuck in their shoot pattern for far too long. IDPD inspectors often shoot their shots at you even though you are far beyond thier reach.
- The game is unbalanced as a result of some changes made during the Early Access phase and too often the difficulty of situations feel cheap as it was beyond the player's control.
- Looping is a mess; prepared to be swarmed by flies, scorpions, snipers and\or assassins unless you have a powerful weapon or skill.
- I feel the game relies too heavily on RNG this is seen clearly with the seed generation and weapon drops the for Daily and Weekly Challenges.
- Tiered weapon distribution needs some work still. At 'late game' pre-loop, you shouldn't even be given 'beginning tier' weapons any more or rather they should drop less in my opinion.
- You tell me to avoid weapons chests and when I do you give me 2 wrenches and a low tier bullet weapon mid game. What kind of rubbish is that?
- Secret levels aren't really interesting to be honest. I wish there were unique weapons you could only attain on those levels like how it was done in Spelunky.
- It makes no sense to me why the player is the only one affected by Flame Trap in the Wasteland and Spider Webs in the Caves. Enemies should not be able to walk or run full speed on the webs except for the spiders and crystals.
- I wish the scoring system used for the Daily\Weekly Challenge Leader board rankings relied on something more than just kills, something like a point system for instance.
* Points based on enemy types (1pts - Maggot, 3pts - Big Maggot, 5pts - Bandit, 15pts - Scorpion, 30pts - Golden Scorpion etc.)
* 1.0		- Loop 0 multiplier (increments by 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 2.0 etc.)
* 100pts	- Per level, affected by the Loop Multiplier
* 250pts	- Secret levels (multiples of 250)
* 500pts	- Defeating bosses (multiples of 500)
* 750pts	- Crown raid + taking crowns
* 1000pts	- IDPD HQ raid

Verdict  Nuclear Throne is an extremely enjoyable and frantic rogue-lite which requires your utmost attention as any wrong slip will result in your death. Sometimes you get a crap seed where you get murdered instantly, don't get the right mutations or weapons and other times you get all the right mutations and weapons and go on a murderous rampage. That feeling is exhilarating. However it was released with various bugs that should've been fixed while in Early Access and it unfortunately represents the first strike against Vlambeer's perfect or near perfect record.

So can I recommend you buy this game, sadly no, not with all the issues currently surrounding it which is a shame as the game is really enjoyable. However, if you can overlook the Cons and Irritations and understand that you're purchasing an unfinished game then by all means go for it, otherwise it's best to wait a while until the bugs\issues are fixed.

- Review Update: (2016-02-22 Update 98) -
VerdictNuclear Throne is an extremely enjoyable and frantic rogue-lite which requires your utmost attention as any wrong slip will result in your death. Sometimes you get a crap seed where you get murdered instantly, don't get the right mutations or weapons and other times you get all the right mutations and weapons and go on a murderous rampage. That feeling is exhilarating. Although it was released in a broken manner, it seems Vlambeer was hard at work to fix all\most of what was broken and I'm happy to sasy that I'm glad they did.

So can I recommend you buy this game now after Update 98, sadly still no. Don't get me wrong Update 98 fixed some things like the Daily\Weekly Challenges and some other issues but the game is still buggy and crashes from time to time for no reason.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fast, fun and frequently updated. Nuclear Throne is highly replayable and satisfying.

The enemies are varied, the guns each feel different and there's a decent level of strategy over randomness with weapon, mutation and character selection. It feels quite balanced, even whilst in early access, and Vlambeer tweak and update the game on a very frequent schedule (about weekly, so far as I have seen).

There is the promise of eventual online co-op and perhaps a versus mode too, but even without those I would recommend the game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy this game! It's fun, it's rich in variety, it's interesting and it's got great music.

Don't get put off by the early access lable - this is not one of those games you buy just for the promises. The game already feels finished, with a wide variety of characters to choose from. With one active and one passive special ability they all play differently, some only a little and some a lot (samurai-chicken!).
Ther is new stuff to discover even after you've played for a long time, secrets to discover, new awesome weapons to find, secret rooms and so on. And the developers are doing almost weekly updates, sometimes bigger, sometimes smaller, so there is still lots of content coming on top of that.

The gameplay mechanic is very simple, as you go around shooting everybody while trying to avoid enemies and projectiles. There is some character progression through various mutations, but the game is still mostly based on your skill in aiming and evading.
For me it's not a game to be playing for hours on end, but rather a few runs whenever I find the time.
Oh, and did I already mention the game has great music?

For me this is definitely the best indie game this year.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review as of 23 hours of gameplay:
Nuclear Throne is a top down shooter roguelike mix of extreme difficulty. The game in its current state has plenty of characters each with their own passive and active abilities, accounting for many different playstyles. The game is randomly generated and extremely difficult leaving a lot of replayability. There are a large number of weapons and a few secrets to be found. Throughout the game you will collect rads to level up. When you leave a floor in which you levelled up you get to choose from one of four mutations, which change the way certain things work. This game is a full reccommendation from me.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFast, hectic and difficult. This top-down bullet-hell rouge-like, despite being in early access, has great depth of play, brilliant weapon and charecter selection and fantastic feeling of reward. Your play style will be constantly changing as you get farther and discover better and more over-powered cobinations of mutations and weapons (supposing you don't immedietly snap to the laser weapons.) And this game isn't afraid at all to rub how OP you can get right in your nose. Feel the power and steam roll the game before one cocky mistake lands you in the soup, and the game claims it all from you again, leaving you to sit and wonder at the campfire once more: will I ever reach the Nuclear Throne?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing the game from when it first came around on Steam, I have to say this game is just awesome. While most people are driven away by the Early Access label, being in early access is what kept me playing this game more and more. When I first got it, it was a lot of fun. With every week that came, a new update came for the game. New content, fixes, balancing, and more. This is what kept me returning to it. Every week I would check if the new update came out, to see if they added a new area, new weapon, or sometimes even a new character. Overall, this game is fast paced and tons of fun. In some areas it can become a nightmare with all the bullets, but with each new update they are balancing certains aspects of the game to keep it a bit more fair. Every time you die, you can't really blame the game. All your mistakes are just because of you, and it can take a long time to get pretty good at the game.

So, yeah, pretty awesome game.

Early Access Review

I couldn't recommend this game without saying one thing. It's friggin' awesome. For a cheap title, it's a hell lotta' fun.

For one, it's filled with a ton of characters with various risks vs. rewards and ultimately takes a ton of skill, time, and effort to find your best character, playstyle, and luck, of course! Go full dakka as Steroids? Or equip yourself with a melee and a weapon for some more utility? Ultimately, it comes down to preference. The art so far for this game is amazing. The music is great, rememberable, something that you wouldn't mind listening to outside of playing it. Enemy design is great, easy to follow patterns, but when the going gets tough, it gets tough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fast intense arcade-like action. The gameplay focuses on shooting, bullet hell-style dodging and short-term planning.
Rounds are bite-sized and you can instantly retry after dying, but you'll likely take a few minutes to build concentration.

Very polished for an early access game, and gets updated frequently. With different characters, secret unlockables and lots of mutations/skills, there's already a lot of content.

Nuclear Throne is fairly hard - you easily get cornered and die very quickly.
Due to smooth controls the game feels mostly fair, but there's some enemies and situations you can just do very little against.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nuclear Throne is an early access masterpiece. It recieves mostly weekly updates, and has been worth much more than the asking price for a long time, plus the developers do a good job of listening to user feedback.

As for the game, it is infinitely replayable, and has no end. You will never stop improving. In the begining you may find it hard to avoid bullets, or you may not have the hang of ammo management, so you may die early. However as you play you will get farther and farther, and see more and more. Eventually you will beat the final boss, and your reward is looping back to the begining, with a much harder version of the game. When you beat the boss again, you will keep looping, and it will keep getting harder and harder, and weapons will keep getting cooler and cooler, until you die. There is something very rewarding about getting to levels flooded with hundreds of enemies, and bosses too, and fighting your way through them with the same amount of health you had at level 1, like a god.

It's content rich, has strong enemy variety, has infinite replayability, has good developers, has lots of weapons, has many diverse characters that change how you play the game, has many secrets, has competitive daily runs, is challenging no matter how much you improve, is cheap, and is constantly being updated. I couldn't reccommend this game enough.

Cons: There are certainly bugs, and WIP graphics in places, as this is early access, and it's still being developed. However anything game breaking is usually hotfixed so that there is never a moment where you straight up cannot play the game. The game also wipes progress every update, however this isn't a big issue because the only unlockables in the game, characters, can easily be unlocked all in one short run. The only inconvenience this causes is your proto chest and golden weapons are wiped, which aren't very commonly used features anyways. Finally, co-op is not very good in it's current state, so if you are buying this to play with a friend, I'll tell you right now that it will just make the game a lot harder and more confusing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An entertaining hybrid of shmup and rpg tied together with reasonably diverting fluff and art.  The combination of shoot'n'dodge and character builder really emphasizes the complexity and importance of decision-making.   I like it.  It's a game to play with music pumping and wanting to get pumped up in 10 minutes- if you can make it even one play through.  I'd almost say it's an excellent lunchbreak speed-game in the sense of Strange Adventures in Infinite Space.  Semi-spoilers ah.. it's obvious that the draw is long-lasting complexity and high-skill ceiling, not tweests, right?

The shooting and movement is very well-executed.  Combined with the screen shake, the experience is intense and embracing.   The situations you find yourself in vary a great deal, a consequence of weapon variety, enemy attack types, and  character's and talents.

Balance, particularly for talents, is beta from my perspective.  I've been playing YV and Steroids, who both feature high-dps and emphasis on weapon combos, which could color my opinion.    The playstyle varies quite a bit between characters due to a variety of unique characteristics.  If I were better at dodging, I might prefer characters that are required to dodge more bullets due to comparatively low dps and talents that do little to shorten or ease a fight or improve my ability to panic spam.  Many of those heroes have traits that improve their resources.  Anyway, it is beta and balance is indisuptably a work in progress.

A significant example of the design philosophy is the cursed weapons available at this time.  If you pick them up, you can only exchange them for other cursed weapons.  You get more ammo for those weapons though.  This is a principle that pervades the game; even though talents are never generally bad, they are very often situationally useless.  What good is  a bonus to energy weapon damage or kinetic ammo supply if you don't have those weapons?    Optimization in specific utility (for short-term survival or situations that are not sustainable or easily achievable) or for general viability of your build are very important and I'd hazard most players will spent some time at the inter-level level screen, simple as it is.


It was worth it at $12 for me, but if you want it for less, it won't go on sale until after release.

the game is very very difficult and not for the faint of heart
it will make you mad and it will frustrate the hell out of you but you can never get mad at the game because the game never throws anything unfair at you
almost always it wil be your fault that you died
but everytime you just need to accept it and start again

the game has daily runs, which is a map that isnt procedurally generated, so everyone plays the same version
the longer you go the higher you go up on the leaderboards, which adds a competative aspect to the game and an incentive to get better

the game also has a background story which can be very interesting to some
its a post-apocalyptic sci-fi wasteland dystopian world that can lead to a lot of lore
and it shines very well through the sound design and art style of nuclear throne.

for 13 dollars i could not recommend a better game
and as it is in early access its only going to get better and better which is a very good thing for a game like this

reviewText:
UPDATED 1.0 REVIEW:

First let us look back to my review on August 26th 2014!
---
Alpha based review:

Just like their previous games Vlambeer hits the nail on it's head by once again giving the player INSTANT satisfaction, on easy to LEARN, but hard to MASTER gameplay. This all nicely shown in a pixel art style that representative, fun and appealling.
---

New review:
First off: This is one of the best Early Acces game releases, probably the best. With their mentality to really get everything out of EA they went and did it. Every Tuesday and Thursday on of the team was streaming: showing new projects in the developent, streaming the game, having fun with new ideas, testing new features, answering questions. They have truelly been an inspiration for me in the past 1.5 years I have followed them develop this game. We were able to see it from beginning to end and we got delivered what they were promised.

The Good:
- The game play: it's fast and fun
- Instant gratification: Jump right into the action, no bla bla. (If you get the joke, well done).
Lot's of characters, weapons and MUTATIONS: so many combinations to try out, you keep combining and you have to, as everything is randomly found.
- Good challenge: If you're not a very skilled player, this game is still fun, you will still have a feeling of achievement after ending a run. For the high skilled: try staying alive when you are looped! More bosses, more environments, harder enemies!
- Audio: The reason I bought the game. The rough sounds gives a tough feel, a super attitude to a game that oozes with action. Every gun feels better.
- Price: €12,99, that's not pricey for a single/co-op game.

The Bad:
- Crashes: Game crashes when immediately leaving the co-op menu, after entering.
- Stats: Stats do not load.

The Ugly:
- Some graphic bugs: Shovel looks weird, sometimes a glitch.

Conclusion:
I highly recommend this game, if you like top down shooters, guns blazing, rough audio, a cool soundtrack and EXPLOSIONS! So much fun and hard to get through. You'll easily get you money out of it!

Thanks JW + Rami (Vlambeer) and team.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNuclear Throne is a rogue-like twin-stick shooter. You play as one of the many characters and fight to claim your rite to sit on the nuclear throne. There are a lot of weapons, and the difficulty is very high. It's very fast-paced, and extremely enjoyable. The game is constantly being developed, which is really nice. It makes it so there are fresh things almost every week. One drawback is that unlocks (and settings) are reset whenever it updates, which is almost every week. Luckily most of the characters have really easy unlocks and take 1 run to get for the most part. Even if you're one of those people who is wary of early-access games, this game is at an extremely playable state, and even if the game was considered finished" at this point i would still be very happy with it. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes rogue-likes."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, this is one of my favorite games ever. If you liked Castle Crashers or The Binding of Isaac, you'll LOVE this.

Nuclear throne is a game where all you do is shoot.
shoot, shoot, shoot. Shoot stuff till it's dead. It's got nice retro graphics and easy-to-get-used-to controls.
I REALLY reccomend this game to almost any gamer. BUT! And this is a big but...
This game is harder than a rock. I've played two days straight almost nonstop, and I've only gotten halfway to the Nuclear Throne.

So, as I said, this game is great, and supplies you with hours upon hours of fun.
Let's get to the details,

CONTROLS:
As I said, this game has easy controls. Rightclick for special ability, left click to shoot, WASD to move, y'know, the usual. Very easy to get used to.

Difficulty:
HARD. VERY, VERY, VEEEEEEEEEERY HARD. However this doesn't ruin the game. If it wasn't hard you could finish the game within a day. If you like games where every single run you beat the game, don't get this one.

Gameplay:
The basic gameplay elements are simple: Dodge bullets and shoot enemies. The more you kill enemies, the less stuff to dodge (Obviously). Killing enemies gives you radiation, which is this game's exp system. Why radiation helps you... I'll explain later. Once you kill all the enemies in the area, you go through a portal. If you managed to level up in the last area, you get to select a mutation. All the mutations make very noticable changes and some of them have a huge effect on how you play.

STORY:
There was a huge nuclear war. And you play as mutants. Except for one character.
But anyway, from what I can tell, the story goes like this...
A mutant tells all his mutant friends that he saw the mythical Nuclear Throne" (I think whatever character you used in y your current run plays the role of this mutant). So he/she goes on a quest to rule the world by getting to the throne. I can't really tell after that so MOVING ON TOOOO.....

CHARACTERS:
The characters are all unique in their own way
date: and fit almost every playstyle available. (Also
recommended: every character other than rogue is a mutant. EXCEPT for I.D.P.D. Thats why the mutants need radiation.)\nRogue- The only human character you can play as in the game. Every time he's attacked
hoursPlayed: he lets out a blue explosion killing anything around him. The only problem is he's constantly being chased down by the I.D.P.D
voteText: which are basicallly insterstellar space police. His special ability is an airstrike.\nHorror- The hardest character to unlock in my opinion. To unlock horror
helpfulPercent: you must skip a radiation canister (exp crate)
votesHelpful: then on the next area
votesTotal: skip a BIG radiation canister (If you don't get those canisters in a row
votesFunny: just keep skipping regular canisters until you find a big one. Skip it
commentsCount: and you're good to go!). On the NEXT area
column16: if you see a radiation canister
column17: the hostile version of horror should emerge. He attacks you a lot. And does a lot of damage. Anyway
column18: kill horror
column19: and you've unlocked him! Horror's passive ability is getting an extra mutation choice when he levels. His special ability is a radiation beam that uses exp for ammo. If you kill an enemy with it
column20: the rads you used to kill it are returned to you.\nRebel- I like this character. Rebel's passive is that whenever he enters a portal
column21: he has a chance to heal 0-2 health. His special is exchanging one health to summon a minion. The minion dies on it's own eventually.\nChicken- The only character who starts with a melee weapon! Chicken's passive ability is that when she dies
column22: she runs around headless for 5 seconds. She can attack when headless. If you get health in any way when headless
column23: you grow your head back
column24: reviving yourself. Each death removes one max health
column25:
though. Her special is throwing whatever is in her hand. throwing does a LOT OF DAMAGE.
Steroids- His passive is starting with two weapons which are both fully loaded. All weapons you pick up with Steroids is fully automatic. His special is that he always holds both weapons he has equipped. He's also RIIIIIPPED.
Robot- His passive is finding better weapons earlier than other characters. He can eat guns for ammunition or health. He's also kind of like a dog. SO cute.
Y.V- IS illuminati. Passive is faster rate of fire. He starts with a golden revolver
column26: which has more firing speed than a regular revolver. His special is a shot with 2x power. Also
column27: he has a secret ability. (Hint: press all the keys on your keyboard. You'll find out eventually.)\nPlant- He's faster than everyone else. He can also trap enemys in snares with his special ability.\nMelting- His passive isn't very passive. It actually affects the entire game. Like
column29: 3 quarters of the enemies in this game can one-shot him. His max health is 2
column30: but he gets a little more xp. He can detonate the corpses of people he's killed. This is a key gameplay element to Melting. Without it
column31: he'd be useless.\nEyes- Can see better in dark areas like the sewer. He also has telekenesis
column34:
and chests. It also pushes away projectiles.
Crystal- Starts with 10 health instead of 8 or 2. He can also turn  into an almost inpenatrable crystal shard which can also deflect some projectiles.
Fish- Starts with more ammo. Fish can roll.

Ok
column35: sorry for the frickin' essay I just wrote. It's only because this game deserves my time. It's amazingly well developed.\n\nOk
column37:
the creators of this masterpiece:
Thanks for making ANOTHER great game. You guys are legendary. I just have a FEW suggestions:

Up Melting's max health to 4. 2 is quite pitiful.
Nerf the spider cave's crystal-laser things.
Add more story! Make the player feel like the mutants are in a struggle for power. Make it have more feeling.
Sometimes when I die

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nuclear throne is hands down one of my favorite games. Playing it throughout all the updates, changes, and bug fixes is like watching someone grow up. It might be a challenging game at first, but if you keep on practicing and never give up hope of reaching the throne, you'll be brandishing golden weapons and looping in no time. Now, the price of this game while it is still in early access might scare away some people, but the game hardly has any bugs, and any error that is reported will most likely be fixed in the weekly updates.

BUT

if you give up/get angry easily and have trouble learning from mistakes, I do not reccomend this game. If you die, you DO start over from the begginging. There are no save points, no permanent unlocks (yet), and NO MERCY.

So yes, I do reccomend Nuclear Throne to those who can handle it. Vlambeer has created another 8-bit bullet hell masterpiece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is challenging, and by that I mean rage-inducingly difficult. It is very fast-paced, and unpredictable. Each playthrough can last only mere minutes. In my first 2 hours of playing, I managed over 50 plays, none of which were successful. Don't let that scare you off though, I enjoyed every moment of it.
The random generation of levels, enemies and drops keeps you constantly on your toes. Many of the enemies have some nasty suprises in store. Each of the character has their own special ability. Even the upgrades you choose from as you progress are randomized.
I would like to see some more melee weapons added to the game as I tend to favor the sledgehammer when I find it. The variety of the guns I find amazing, especially the Triple Machine Gun. Don't underestimate any of the weapons, they all have their strengths, except maybe the screwdriver.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPreviously I made a negative review for this game. When I was writing that review I failed to notice that even though each update comes with a new bug, it also comes with a new feature. This is one of the reasons Nuclear Throne is such an amazing game, and it's simply because the dev team truely cares for it. It's a game focused around having a bullet for every inch of your screen, but who cares. The insane gameplay gives no time to rest as you are forced to each level in an infinite loop constantly finding better loot, and harder enemies. The game takes a while to learn, and it will be a good week before you even reach the frozen city, or big dog, but when you do it's the best feeling in the world. Nuclear Throne features a huge roster of characters that have no gimmicks that force you into a certain gamestyle, but rather unique features that you can addapt within your own game style. (Instead of doing more melee damage and less gun damage slo mo) The game never seems to punish you for exploring a new game style and instead seems to encourage that there truely isn't a meta and that you must discover your own. Sadly the free copy of the game I recieved was given to someone who has ill taste for these sorts of games but even with that he still had a hell of a lot of fun. Overall it's a game that even with it's bugs, is so much fun it's easy to ignore. Easy 10 outta 10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPreviously I made a negative review for this game. When I was writing that review I failed to notice that even though each update comes with a new bug, it also comes with a new feature. This is one of the reasons Nuclear Throne is such an amazing game, and it's simply because the dev team truely cares for it. It's a game focused around having a bullet for every inch of your screen, but who cares. The insane gameplay gives no time to rest as you are forced to each level in an infinite loop constantly finding better loot, and harder enemies. The game takes a while to learn, and it will be a good week before you even reach the frozen city, or big dog, but when you do it's the best feeling in the world. Nuclear Throne features a huge roster of characters that have no gimmicks that force you into a certain gamestyle, but rather unique features that you can addapt within your own game style. (Instead of doing more melee damage and less gun damage slo mo) The game never seems to punish you for exploring a new game style and instead seems to encourage that there truely isn't a meta and that you must discover your own. Sadly the free copy of the game I recieved was given to someone who has ill taste for these sorts of games but even with that he still had a hell of a lot of fun. Overall it's a game that even with it's bugs, is so much fun it's easy to ignore. Easy 10 outta 10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNuclear Throne is a rougelike game where you play as one of 12 characters. Each character has their own special ability. Such as spawning in allies for the cost of health or having the ability to roll. Every time you level up, you get to choose 1 out of 4 upgrades. Once you level up to around level 5, it gets really fun. at around level 9, once you level up again, you get to choose your ultimate mutation. They are different ultimate mutations for each character so you might have to find out for yourself what each mutation does. (or look at the wiki) So it's really fun, many options for gameplay, and a lot of characters and weapons. Would I recommend it? Yeah.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nuclear throne is hands down one of my favorite games. Playing it throughout all the updates, changes, and bug fixes is like watching someone grow up. It might be a challenging game at first, but if you keep on practicing and never give up hope of reaching the throne, you'll be brandishing golden weapons and looping in no time. Now, the price of this game while it is still in early access might scare away some people, but the game hardly has any bugs, and any error that is reported will most likely be fixed in the weekly updates.

BUT

if you give up/get angry easily and have trouble learning from mistakes, I do not reccomend this game. If you die, you DO start over from the begginging. There are no save points, no permanent unlocks (yet), and NO MERCY.

So yes, I do reccomend Nuclear Throne to those who can handle it. Vlambeer has created another 8-bit bullet hell masterpiece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, this is one of my favorite games ever. If you liked Castle Crashers or The Binding of Isaac, you'll LOVE this.

Nuclear throne is a game where all you do is shoot.
shoot, shoot, shoot. Shoot stuff till it's dead. It's got nice retro graphics and easy-to-get-used-to controls.
I REALLY reccomend this game to almost any gamer. BUT! And this is a big but...
This game is harder than a rock. I've played two days straight almost nonstop, and I've only gotten halfway to the Nuclear Throne.

So, as I said, this game is great, and supplies you with hours upon hours of fun.
Let's get to the details,

CONTROLS:
As I said, this game has easy controls. Rightclick for special ability, left click to shoot, WASD to move, y'know, the usual. Very easy to get used to.

Difficulty:
HARD. VERY, VERY, VEEEEEEEEEERY HARD. However this doesn't ruin the game. If it wasn't hard you could finish the game within a day. If you like games where every single run you beat the game, don't get this one.

Gameplay:
The basic gameplay elements are simple: Dodge bullets and shoot enemies. The more you kill enemies, the less stuff to dodge (Obviously). Killing enemies gives you radiation, which is this game's exp system. Why radiation helps you... I'll explain later. Once you kill all the enemies in the area, you go through a portal. If you managed to level up in the last area, you get to select a mutation. All the mutations make very noticable changes and some of them have a huge effect on how you play.

STORY:
There was a huge nuclear war. And you play as mutants. Except for one character.
But anyway, from what I can tell, the story goes like this...
A mutant tells all his mutant friends that he saw the mythical Nuclear Throne" (I think whatever character you used in y your current run plays the role of this mutant). So he/she goes on a quest to rule the world by getting to the throne. I can't really tell after that so MOVING ON TOOOO.....

CHARACTERS:
The characters are all unique in their own way
date: and fit almost every playstyle available. (Also
recommended: every character other than rogue is a mutant. EXCEPT for I.D.P.D. Thats why the mutants need radiation.)\nRogue- The only human character you can play as in the game. Every time he's attacked
hoursPlayed: he lets out a blue explosion killing anything around him. The only problem is he's constantly being chased down by the I.D.P.D
voteText: which are basicallly insterstellar space police. His special ability is an airstrike.\nHorror- The hardest character to unlock in my opinion. To unlock horror
helpfulPercent: you must skip a radiation canister (exp crate)
votesHelpful: then on the next area
votesTotal: skip a BIG radiation canister (If you don't get those canisters in a row
votesFunny: just keep skipping regular canisters until you find a big one. Skip it
commentsCount: and you're good to go!). On the NEXT area
column16: if you see a radiation canister
column17: the hostile version of horror should emerge. He attacks you a lot. And does a lot of damage. Anyway
column18: kill horror
column19: and you've unlocked him! Horror's passive ability is getting an extra mutation choice when he levels. His special ability is a radiation beam that uses exp for ammo. If you kill an enemy with it
column20: the rads you used to kill it are returned to you.\nRebel- I like this character. Rebel's passive is that whenever he enters a portal
column21: he has a chance to heal 0-2 health. His special is exchanging one health to summon a minion. The minion dies on it's own eventually.\nChicken- The only character who starts with a melee weapon! Chicken's passive ability is that when she dies
column22: she runs around headless for 5 seconds. She can attack when headless. If you get health in any way when headless
column23: you grow your head back
column24: reviving yourself. Each death removes one max health
column25:
though. Her special is throwing whatever is in her hand. throwing does a LOT OF DAMAGE.
Steroids- His passive is starting with two weapons which are both fully loaded. All weapons you pick up with Steroids is fully automatic. His special is that he always holds both weapons he has equipped. He's also RIIIIIPPED.
Robot- His passive is finding better weapons earlier than other characters. He can eat guns for ammunition or health. He's also kind of like a dog. SO cute.
Y.V- IS illuminati. Passive is faster rate of fire. He starts with a golden revolver
column26: which has more firing speed than a regular revolver. His special is a shot with 2x power. Also
column27: he has a secret ability. (Hint: press all the keys on your keyboard. You'll find out eventually.)\nPlant- He's faster than everyone else. He can also trap enemys in snares with his special ability.\nMelting- His passive isn't very passive. It actually affects the entire game. Like
column29: 3 quarters of the enemies in this game can one-shot him. His max health is 2
column30: but he gets a little more xp. He can detonate the corpses of people he's killed. This is a key gameplay element to Melting. Without it
column31: he'd be useless.\nEyes- Can see better in dark areas like the sewer. He also has telekenesis
column34:
and chests. It also pushes away projectiles.
Crystal- Starts with 10 health instead of 8 or 2. He can also turn  into an almost inpenatrable crystal shard which can also deflect some projectiles.
Fish- Starts with more ammo. Fish can roll.

Ok
column35: sorry for the frickin' essay I just wrote. It's only because this game deserves my time. It's amazingly well developed.\n\nOk
column37:
the creators of this masterpiece:
Thanks for making ANOTHER great game. You guys are legendary. I just have a FEW suggestions:

Up Melting's max health to 4. 2 is quite pitiful.
Nerf the spider cave's crystal-laser things.
Add more story! Make the player feel like the mutants are in a struggle for power. Make it have more feeling.
Sometimes when I die
column38: my game freezes and I have to restart my laptop to actually close the game. Kind of annoying.\nThat's really all I can suggest. Otherwise
column39: this game is PERFECT.\n\nP.S. Where is that Ridiculous Fishing update? Sorry if you've already announced something
column40: but I REALLY wanted an update for one of my favorite IOS games!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to start this by saying this is a great game, even though its has its fair shares of flaws. Nuclear Throne is one of my favorate games even thouugh it doesn't show, because the hours I played it I was offline. For a game that is still in development its have countless hours of gameplay and if pretty well developed. There is a crazy amount of weapons and enemies, which are all well rounded and most have variety. It is being updated every Saturday which is nice unlike games like Rust that gets updated every seven or eight months. There are daily runs so you can challenge your freinds and people from around the world.
Now to talk about the flaws in the game, there are mostly minor bugs most you wont see. The boss intro screen is pixleated, and some enemies  appear a little low rez but other wise it looks great ( l love the theme that they have designed) The biggest problem I have with the game what keeps me from finishing a run is it has a 30FPS lock, I am so used to playing games at 60 or higher that i have headaces if I play for a while.
Final toughts on the game is that there is no reason you should not get this, it is very well rounded and challenging there is countless hours of gameplay and you will definaltly get you moneys woth out of it.

The basic gameplay elements are simple: Dodge bullets and shoot enemies. The more you kill enemies, the less stuff to dodge (Obviously). Killing enemies gives you radiation, which is this game's exp system. Why radiation helps you... I'll explain later. Once you kill all the enemies in the area, you go through a portal. If you managed to level up in the last area, you get to select a mutation. All the mutations make very noticable changes and some of them have a huge effect on how you play.

STORY:
There was a huge nuclear war. And you play as mutants. Except for one character.
But anyway, from what I can tell, the story goes like this...
A mutant tells all his mutant friends that he saw the mythical Nuclear Throne" (I think whatever character you used in y your current run plays the role of this mutant). So he/she goes on a quest to rule the world by getting to the throne. I can't really tell after that so MOVING ON TOOOO.....

CHARACTERS:
The characters are all unique in their own way
date: and fit almost every playstyle available. (Also
recommended: every character other than rogue is a mutant. EXCEPT for I.D.P.D. Thats why the mutants need radiation.)\nRogue- The only human character you can play as in the game. Every time he's attacked
hoursPlayed: he lets out a blue explosion killing anything around him. The only problem is he's constantly being chased down by the I.D.P.D
voteText: which are basicallly insterstellar space police. His special ability is an airstrike.\nHorror- The hardest character to unlock in my opinion. To unlock horror
helpfulPercent: you must skip a radiation canister (exp crate)
votesHelpful: then on the next area
votesTotal: skip a BIG radiation canister (If you don't get those canisters in a row
votesFunny: just keep skipping regular canisters until you find a big one. Skip it
commentsCount: and you're good to go!). On the NEXT area
column16: if you see a radiation canister
column17: the hostile version of horror should emerge. He attacks you a lot. And does a lot of damage. Anyway
column18: kill horror
column19: and you've unlocked him! Horror's passive ability is getting an extra mutation choice when he levels. His special ability is a radiation beam that uses exp for ammo. If you kill an enemy with it
column20: the rads you used to kill it are returned to you.\nRebel- I like this character. Rebel's passive is that whenever he enters a portal
column21: he has a chance to heal 0-2 health. His special is exchanging one health to summon a minion. The minion dies on it's own eventually.\nChicken- The only character who starts with a melee weapon! Chicken's passive ability is that when she dies
column22: she runs around headless for 5 seconds. She can attack when headless. If you get health in any way when headless
column23: you grow your head back
column24: reviving yourself. Each death removes one max health
column25:
though. Her special is throwing whatever is in her hand. throwing does a LOT OF DAMAGE.
Steroids- His passive is starting with two weapons which are both fully loaded. All weapons you pick up with Steroids is fully automatic. His special is that he always holds both weapons he has equipped. He's also RIIIIIPPED.
Robot- His passive is finding better weapons earlier than other characters. He can eat guns for ammunition or health. He's also kind of like a dog. SO cute.
Y.V- IS illuminati. Passive is faster rate of fire. He starts with a golden revolver
column26: which has more firing speed than a regular revolver. His special is a shot with 2x power. Also

column31: he'd be useless.\nEyes- Can see better in dark areas like the sewer. He also has telekenesis
column34:
and chests. It also pushes away projectiles.
Crystal- Starts with 10 health instead of 8 or 2. He can also turn  into an almost inpenatrable crystal shard which can also deflect some projectiles.
Fish- Starts with more ammo. Fish can roll.

Ok
column35: sorry for the frickin' essay I just wrote. It's only because this game deserves my time. It's amazingly well developed.\n\nOk
column37:
the creators of this masterpiece:

Add more story! Make the player feel like the mutants are in a struggle for power. Make it have more feeling.
Sometimes when I die

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. It's rare that I ever put as much time into a game as I have with this one, and I'm not even close to considering stopping yet. The combat is rarely an issue, and every level provides a new type of challenge to overcome. 12 different characters are featured, each with their own unique passive and active, and all offering a different play style. While some mutations may be better than others, it's impossible to go wrong with mutation choices as they all offer a worthwhile upgrade. All of this combined into an endless roguelike with countless different weapons makes for an amazing experience...
If you're patient. The flip side to this game is that it is BRUTALLY difficult. To master this game, unless you're one of those people who's just amazing at video games, you will need time. A lot of it. You will die hundreds, if not thousands of times to mistakes you can't believe you made. I'm approaching 200 hours in this game and I still have rage-inducing deaths on the scrapyard in daily runs.
All in all, buy this game! But do so knowing that it will be frustrating and time-consuming to master.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of a very very very small handful of games where i can play for 10 minutes and be immensely satisfied, because the pure play-by-play speed of Nuclear Throne ♥♥♥♥s you up on a vague cousin to adrenaline that only happens when you play a ludicrously over-the-top video game that pushes you to act immediately with zero sympathy for your failures. There is no good luck in Nuclear Throne, only bad luck, because a random generated map that'd be considered good luck" is still a frenzied maze of bullets and action that you have to act on pure reflex to conquer

And with more content coming out on a near-weekly basis? Hell yes I'm glad i payed full price+early access bonus to get this now."

reviewText:
You get to be a tiangular God of guns who stabs people to death with a screwdriver, and spawns with the blare of an airhorn.
DANK/10


But for real:
A very fast paced, bullet hell of a rogue-like. Lots of guns, some simple, some extravagent, some just plain OP as heckie.
A number of varied characters to give you different playstyles with their passive, and active abilities. Each run different by level design, what drops you find, and what additional passive abilities you unlock as you level up.

The music is pretty cool, the in-game visuals, and splash arts for characters are great. Replayability is astounding, and the game gets hella hard as you go, but not a punishing hard, it's pretty clear as to how and why you got shot in the face by the bird with an assault rifle on the other side of the room.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is ridiculously good action packed dual stick rouge like shooter!!11!11one111

This game is exceptional in many ways but one of them is the unevitability of horrible death, for most of us before reaching the Nuclear Throne.

Some people can't even play this game because they hate losing. Somehow, for me the reward from pwning in Nuclear Throne is so big I keep playing it almost every day until my rage pool is filled which is usually between

- 1 to 5 deaths
- 5 to 30 minutes

a session on average. The game is so hard and rage inducing, I need to learn it over multiple days... I played thousands of videogames so I'm kinda surprised this one motivates me enough to put in so much effort... I'm impressed.

- Amazing pixel graphics.
- Smooth dual stick controls.
- Beautiful map generator.
- Map awarenes required to survive.
- Mad skill cap.
- Colorful characters.
- Crazy Weapons.
- The amazing portal animation with fancy words of wisdom.

Note that I enjoy the game on xbox controller and I wouldn't bother with ridiculously accurate mouse and keyboard.

At the time of writing - if I should reccommend a single videogame to a player who enjoys challenge, it would be Nuclear Throne. Best blind buy ever.
